While notable hedge fund firms such asÂ David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital,Â Dan Loeb's Third Point andÂ David Tepper's Appaloosa Management trimmed or exited their Apple (AAPL) stake in the first quarter, one famously skittish tech investor made a massive grab for the iPhone makerÂ â and reaped impressive returns.Here are some of the best and worst calls in Q1 by high-profileÂ investors and hedge funds, as disclosed by their latest 13F filings. Rank-and-file investors closely track this regulatory data to get a sense of where the "smart money" is being put to work in the stock market.Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) loaded upÂ on Apple in the first quarter, swelling its stake in the tech titanÂ by more than 125% vs. the previous quarter to a total of 129.4 million shares. Shares of Apple haveÂ continued to sizzleÂ in the second quarter of 2017, adding 8.8% through May 15 to take year-to-date gains to 35.5%.By comparison, the S&P 500 has gainedÂ roughly 2% so far in Q2 and 8% year to date, while the Dow Jones industrial average isÂ up roughly 2% and 7% over the respective periods. And that's with Apple as the biggest weighting in both indexes.Buffett described Apple's resonance with customers as "amazing" in a recent CNBC interview. He also said Berkshire used its knowledge of the furniture business to evaluate Apple's worth and its edge over rivals.Apple shares edged down 0.15% to 155.47, their straight modest decline.Another move that paid off forÂ Buffett, who is known to prize more established companies with an "economic moat" or durable competitive advantage: avoidingÂ the flash and dazzle of one hotÂ IPO.Snapchat owner Snap (SNAP)Â was snubbed by Buffett but scooped up by Third Point, Appaloosa and George Soros' Soros Fund Management, to their cost. Snap stock has lost 8% in Q2 and sits 17% below its closing price of 24.48 on March 2, whenÂ it made its highly anticipated stock market debut.Still, the hedge funds snapping up the stock may view it as an investment with solid long-term potential.Snap rose 0.1% to 20.76 after big gains the prior two sessions from last Thursday's post-IPO lows.In one of its biggest and best Q1 moves, Soros hikedÂ its position inÂ Facebook (FB) by more than 80%Â last quarter. TheÂ social networking leader has advanced 6% in the second quarter to date, building on aÂ win streak that has seen the stock climb by more than 30% year to date.Soros Fund Management also upped its Goldman Sachs (GS) position by about 40% to 86,000 shares, with less luck.Goldman Sachs has slid a further 2% since the start of April, taking 2017's losses to nearly 6%. The S&P financial sector is flat so far in Q2 and up a mere 2.5% year to date, lagging the broad S&P 500.Soros' hedge fund may be buying the dip in financial stocks, anticipating a resumption in their five-year rally should improving economic conditions keep the Fed's tightening plans on pace.Facebook fell 0.3% to 149.78 as it consolidates tightly. Goldman rose 02.% to 225.60, still below its 50-day line.In Q1, Berkshire offloaded shares of International Business Machines (IBM), the seventh largest Dow component, and 21stÂ Century Fox (FOX), which has been hit hard by scandals, in a big way.Dumping thoseÂ stocks has buoyed Berkshire's investment portfolio. Shares of both companies are well off their recent 52-week highs. So far in Q2, IBM has tumbled 12% and Fox 13%, extending their hobbled run year to date.IBM rose 1.4%, adding to Monday's gains after tumbling sharply. Fox slid 1.4% extending its sell-off.In Q1, Berkshire grew itsÂ American Airlines (AAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) stakes significantly, maintained a position in United Airlines (UAL) and pared back Delta Air Lines (DAL).Those have been smart moves overall. Airline stocks have soared since the end of MarchÂ despite adverse publicity, with some firms reporting that traffic growth has outpaced capacity increases.American and United are more than 10% higher in Q2; Southwest and Delta are up nearly 8%.United rose 1.4%, still in buy range. Southwest climbed 0.4% and American 0.6%, just belowÂ entry points. Delta was flat.Appaloosa's huge bet on an American industrial renaissance in Q1 hasn't paid off so far, but that could change. Most analysts remain bullish on the outlook for theÂ industrials and materials sectors. Infrastructure spending under President Trump andÂ China'sÂ One Road, One Belt project are two potential catalystsÂ for companies in these sectors, including steel stocks.In Q2 so far, AK Steel (AKS)Â and Nucor (NUE)Â â Appaloosa's new buys from last quarter â are both in the red, down roughly 21% and 4% respectively. ArcelorMittal (MT), a position in the hedge fund that grew more than 400% in size, has given up 10% over theÂ same period.AK Steel fell 0.5%, Nucor rose 0.3% on Tuesday. ArcelorMittal climbed 2.7%.In Q1, Third Point opened stakes in Parsley Energy (PE), Halcon Resources (HK) andÂ Enerplus (ERF). The hedge fund may be of the view that the energy sector is oversold and could be due for a bounce in the medium term. Sector earnings and oil prices are highly correlatedÂ â and West Texas crude prices averagedÂ $52 a barrel in the first quarter, up more than 50% year over year, following an OPEC-led deal on output cuts.In the near term, however, oil prices and energy stocks have beenÂ under pressure.Halcon has given up nearly 12% in the second quarter, extending 2017 losses to 27%. Parsely and Enerplus haven't fared much betterÂ this quarter, down 0.8% and up 0.8% respectively.Parsley sank 1.3%, Halcon 3.7% and Enerplus 0.5% on Tuesday.RELATED:Buffett's Berkshire Stays Away From Snap, But Not These FundsBuffett, Soros Moves Keep Delta, American In Holding PatternWhat Will Berkshire Filing Show As Loeb Cuts Facebook, Apple Stakes?Why Buffett Still Isn't Sure If He'd Buy Amazon, Alphabet Stock Now

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) hiked its stake in Apple (AAPL) by more than 125% to 129.4Â million shares in the first quarter, and made modest changes to its airlines holdings while avoiding Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP), which went public in March.Meanwhile, Soros Fund Management bought 1.7 million shares of Snap, joining David Tepper'sÂ Appaloosa Management and Dan Loeb's Third Point. Soros also dissolved his firm's positions in Amazon.com (AMZN) and Delta Air Lines (DAL), and added to its stake in Facebook (FB), according to filings late Monday.David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital trimmed its Apple holdings to 4.2 million shares from 6.1 million in Q4, while more than quadrupling its stake in General Motors (GM) to 55 million shares from 13 million.In Q1, Berkshire grew its American Airlines (AAL) stake to 49.3 million shares, up 8.4% vs. the previous quarter, and its investment in Southwest Airlines (LUV) to 47.7 million, up 10.4%. It trimmed its position in Delta to 55 million shares, down 8.3%, while keeping its holdings in United Airlines (UAL) steady at 28.9 million.The regulatory filing confirmed news from early May thatÂ Berkshire's Buffett busily dumpedÂ tech giant IBM (IBM) in Q1. It had 64.6 million shares left at quarter-end, down 20%. (Even IBM Retirement Fund's unloaded 70,000 shares of IBM, leaving it with 12,451 IBM shares in Q1, according to the fund's 13F filing on May 10.)Meanwhile, the conglomerate's massive long-term stakes in Coca-Cola (KO), American Express (AXP) and Kraft Heinz (KHC) were left basically unchanged.Buffett had already said Berkshire more than doubled its Apple holdings in Q1, giving it a 2.5% stake in the iPhone maker's outstanding shares. Berkshire initiated a position in Apple, worth $1.1 billion, in Q1 2016 and doubled down on Apple as the year progressed.By contrast, Appaloosa Management slashed its stake in 2017's best-performingÂ Dow component Apple by a third, to 300,000Â shares, and trimmedÂ Facebook by 12.6%, to 1.9Â million shares in Q1, according to filings from Friday. The company also scooped up 100,000 shares of Snap, which tanked 17.5% last week on a dismal debut earnings reports following its March IPO.Similarly, Third Point exited its 1.85 million-share stake in Apple during Q1, while buying 2.25 million shares of Snap.Shares of Berkshire closed up 0.3% at 163.76 on the stock market today. Apple dipped 0.3%, down from Friday's fresh record high, and Snap rallied 8.4%, after last week's plunge. Facebook eased 0.1%, and IBM added 0.7%.Among Appaloosa's other notable moves, the fund entirely liquidatedÂ its massive stakes in two troubled stocks: chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) andÂ retailer J.C. Penney (JCP).Appaloosa added a 1.6Â million-share stake in Symantec (SYMC), which was leading a cybersecurity stock rally Monday on the heels of a global ransomware attack. Appaloosa also raised its Western Digital (WDC) stake by 16.1% to 1.3 million shares.But the hedge fund's biggest bet seems to be on an American industrial renaissance. It opened positions of roughly half a million shares each in AK Steel (AKS) and Nucor (NUE), while upping ArcelorMittal (MT) by more than 410%, to nearly 5 million shares.Other hefty new positions included Bank of America (BAC) and CBS (CBS) (8.8 million and 1.0 million shares, respectively).Third Point's other moves include adding to positions in T-Mobile (TMUS), Salesforce (CRM), Qualcomm and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD).The fund closed a small stake in Goldman Sachs (GS), and reduced holdings in Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase (JPM).Late Friday, Trian Fund Management also disclosed bigger positions in General Electric (GE) and Procter & Gamble (PG) and a smaller stake in DuPont (DD).RELATED:What Will Berkshire Filing Show As Loeb Cuts Facebook, Apple Stakes?Why Buffett Still Isn't Sure If He'd Buy Amazon, Alphabet Stock Now

More details about President Trump's tax-cut plan are expected this afternoon.Â Among the Dow industrials,Â Travelers (TRV)and United Technologies (UTX)Â rose 1.2% and 1.5%, respectively, in the stock market today. The market for nonresidential construction in the U.S. may be heading for a sharp improvement over the next year based on trends ranging from architectural billings to steel demand, even though recent activity presents a mixed picture.The latest government data show that nonresidential construction spending dipped in August from a month earlier. Year-over-year it rose, though, and economists point to certain metrics that portend a further lift in spending in 2015.The expected increase applies not only to sectors that have already seen a rise in spending, such as retail and office, but also to sectors that have been in a slump, including education and health care.A variety of stocks could benefit from an uptick in nonresidential construction. These range from commercial/industrial construction companies such as Fluor (FLR) and KBR (KBR) to suppliers of construction equipment like United Rentals (URI), Terex (TEX) and Manitowoc (MTW) and steel producers like Nucor (NUE).One of the metrics analysts and economists are watching is the Architectural Billings Index, a measure of design activity and future construction that has reached multiyear highs in recent months.Architects Show OptimismOn Oct. 22, the American Institute of Architects reported that the September score was 55.2, up from 53.0 the month before and 53.8 a year earlier. It was the second-highest reading in over seven years, just behind July's reading of 55.8. A score above 50 indicates an increase in billings. This typically leads to a rise in construction of nonresidential projects.Kermit Baker, the AIA's chief economist, says the third-quarter numbers "are the strongest we've seen since before the downturn.""Design activity is very highly correlated with construction activity," he told IBD, adding that it usually takes nine to 12 months to translate into land-clearing for construction.The lag means "you might not see an immediate impact on steel demand," Morningstar steel-stocks analyst Andrew Lane told IBD. "But it's another bullish indicator for the industry."In its third-quarter earnings release, Charlotte, N.C.-based steel maker Nucor said its fabricated construction products businesses (rebar fabrication, joist and decking and pre-engineered metal buildings) spurred "much stronger profits" than in the second quarter."This performance reflects improving conditions in the nonresidential construction markets," Nucor said, though those markets "remain at historically low levels."Most recent government nonresidential construction numbers show a market still struggling to find its footing after a prolonged downturn.Census Bureau data show that nonresidential construction spending in August fell 1.2% monthly but rose 6% vs. a year ago. September data are due Nov. 3.Seven of 16 nonresidential construction sectors saw spending rise in August. These included office, up 1.1% sequentially and 18.9% year-over-year; manufacturing, up 1.7% and 14.5%, respectively; and lodging, up 0.9% and 10.2%, respectively. Commercial construction, including retail, fell 3.1% on a monthly basis but rose 9.4% year-over-year.The uptick in office-related construction "comes as no surprise," said Anirban Basu, chief economist at Associated Builders and Contractors, an industry trade group. That's because job growth "has accelerated, particularly in office-type jobs" such as professional services."Over the past year we've seen solid growth in office space-related construction, measured in dollar volume," Basu told IBD.Houston, Seattle And San JoseHe calls Houston, Seattle and San Jose, Calif., "standout performers" in this segment, thanks mainly to growth in energy (Houston) and tech (Seattle, San Jose) industries. The retail sector has benefited from "interaction between expanding consumer expenditures and the need to protect market share from online retailers," Basu said."One way for shopping centers to compete with online retail is to improve the shopping experience and convince people to get off their computers and actually go out to shop," he added. "So you see shopping centers investing in the construction of grocery stores or movie theaters to lure people in."Among sectors that saw a slowdown in construction spending in August were health care, down 0.6% monthly and 6.6% year-over-year; and education, down 2% monthly but up 1.9% year-over-year. The numbers should improve in coming months, observers say.Why Education Is ImportantThe AIA's Baker notes that there have been four straight months of gains in institutional billings, a sector that is mostly made up of education and health care but also includes cultural, religious, correctional and sports facilities."That was the sector that had not recovered much, but there's a lot more confidence that we will see an upturn in institutional next year," Baker said. "We are encouraged that there have been four months of upturn, and that the numbers have been accelerating."A rise in construction of education facilities would provide a particularly big boost to nonresidential construction because it's one of the industry's biggest sectors.Education was hit hard by the recession and housing crisis. As property values fell, so did property taxes that finance construction of public schools. But as property values go up there will be more money to spend on schools.Another trend that may help educational facility construction comes from colleges and universities."Many universities are trying to improve the standard of living in the wake of lower enrollment," Basu said. "This has led to plans to improve the quality of both on- and off-campus housing."Meanwhile, the health care sector might see a rise in construction as hospital operators grow more comfortable with ObamaCare."Hospitals took a time out on major construction because they wanted to see the impact of the Affordable Care Act," Basu said. "One of the positive aspects of the ACA is that the level of uncompensated care has fallen. All other things being equal, this improves the finances at hospitals. And anything that improves the finances improves the construction outlook."

The stock market rose, then gave back most of the day's gains Wednesday even after the Federal Reserve made it clear that it's still in no hurry to raise the cost of money. For now, the market's uptrend stayed intact. Most leading stocks did well, but the price gains were mostly accompanied with dull volume. Such action can be expectedâ¦

But a sluggish market poses risks for any new purchases. For those willing to risk today's market, several big-cap leaders are in buy range from their latest base breakouts. Many cyclical stocksâ¦
Major averages ended modestly higher, but pared their gains after initial volatility following the Fed's policy statement.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.2% advance, while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials each finished a little more than 0.1% higher. That was enough for the Dow to eke out a new closing high. Volume was lighter across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.

The Fed noted the economy is growing at a moderate pace and inflation remains below the Fed's goals. It expects interest rates to stay low for a "considerable time" after its bond-buying program ends next month.

Steel makers continued their recent strength as the group scored the day's biggest gain. U.S. Steel (X) surged 10% in heavy volume to its highest level in over three years after saying Tuesday it expects Q3 earnings to be "significantly higher" than current estimates.
Nucor (NUE) leapt 4% in triple normal trade after also guiding its Q3 EPS higher. Steel Dynamics (STLD) rose 4% in above-average trade. The steel producers' industry group was up 4%.

Solar stocks were also among the top movers, led by Canadian Solar's (CSIQ) 7% rally. FBR Capital Markets raised its price target on the solar module maker to 45 from 40, a day after the company said it inked a deal to provide 1.5 megawatts to Kawar Energy for a project in Amman, Jordan.

Steel producer Nucor is acquiring a flat-rolled products mill for $770 million, expanding its footprint in the Midwest and boosting flat-rolled capacity by 16%.
Nucor (NUE) is buying Kentucky-based Gallatin Steel from ArcelorMittal (MT) and Gerdau Ameristeel (GGB). Cash and commercial paper borrowings will fund the deal.
"Importantly, Gallatin will enhance Nucor's current position serving flat-rolled (steel) customers in the growing pipe and tube segment," said Nucor CEO John Ferriola in a press statement.
Shares of the company were up 0.8% on the stock market today.
Gallatin has an annual capacity of 1.8 million tons and will be Nucor's fifth flat-rolled mill. The acquisition is expected to raise Nucor's annual capacity to 13 million tons.
The sale is also part of ArcelorMittal's strategy to selectively divest non-core assets and will allow Gerdau to focus on North American core assets, said both companies in a joint release.

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 held up well Monday, but the Nasdaq took a hit ahead of Tuesday's start of a two-day Federal Reserve meeting.

The Nasdaq slumped 1.1%, weighed down by software and solar names. The Dow edged higher, helped by strength in shares of Pfizer (PFE) and Travelers (TRV). Both stocks rose 1%. The S&P 500 gave up 0.3%.

In the stock market today, Tesla Motors (TSLA) dived nearly 8% after Morgan Stanley reiterated its overweight rating but removed a 320 price target, basically saying the stock has gotten ahead of itself.

Anheuser Busch InBev (BUD) jumped 3% on news it's interested in buying privately held No. 2 brewer SABMiller. Group peer Molson Coors Brewing (TAP) soared 7% on speculation it could be a takeover target down the line.

Big buyers came into steel producer Nucor (NUE) again on news it's buying Gallatin Steel for about $770 million. Shares rose 1.5%. Nucor is still in the early stages of clearing a long consolidation that started in November. IBD's Steel-Producers group now ranks No. 3 in IBD's 197 Industry Group Rankings, up from No. 28 three weeks ago and No. 40 six weeks ago.

Meanwhile, China-based e-commerce firm Alibaba is scheduled to price Thursday night and start trading Friday. The proposed price range is 60-66 a share, but it'll likely move higher due to overwhelming demand. Alibaba will trade under the symbol BABA.

Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Tuesday as an analyst warning on the new Apple iPhone hurt shares of the company and its suppliers.The Nasdaq was off 0.6% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.2%.Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq. Declining stocks had a small edge over advancers on the NYSE while the losers led by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq.Solar energy, automaker, staffing and dairy product companies were among the poorest performers in the stock market today. Tesla (TSLA) skidded more than 3%, sinking deeper below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Metal, retail, utility and real estate investment trust industry groups were some of the best Tuesday.Some suppliers of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone were lower after Credit Suisse warned that the company was cutting back component orders for the iPhone 6S model.Apple shares gapped down to a 3% loss in above-average volume. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 7% in busy trading and fell below the 50-day moving average. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) gapped below its 50-day moving average as it shed 6% in heavy trading.On the plus side, Ruth's Hospitality (RUTH), better known as Ruth's Chris Steak House, cleared the 16.96 buy point of a double-bottom base in active trading.The company beat Q3 earnings expectations a couple of weeks ago as EPS jumped 33%. The restaurant industry group, though, has been trending lower in IBD's group rankings.

Stocks gave up much of their early gains going into the afternoon Wednesday and activity slackened as investors held their breadth in anticipation of the Federal Reserve's announcement on monetary policy at 2 p.m. ET.A shift in interest rates is not expected, but the wording of the Fed's announcement and comments from Fed chief Janet Yellen in a press conference afterward will be closely parsed.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were little changed. Volume was running considerably lighter on both exchanges, but that could change after the Fed's announcement.In the stock market today, steel producers were the hot industry group, with several of the top members gapping up on big volume.Nucor (NUE) raised guidance and rose 4%. U.S. Steel (X) announced strategic changes and gained 9%.Steel Dynamics (STLD) was up nearly 5%.Among IBD 50 stocks, 27 were higher, 23 were lower. The top performer was Chinese automobile website BitAuto (BITA), up nearly 3%. It's been undergoing a correction and is about 20% off its high.Another Chinese stock, YY Inc. (YY), a social media platform, was the worst performer, down 2%.FedEx (FDX) broke out of a flat base in huge volume and was up 3% after issuing a better-than-expected quarterly report. EPS rose 37% from a year ago. The stock has risen five straight days.Thinly traded Apogee Enterprises (APOG), which makes products for the construction industry, was up nearly 9% after posting earnings that were 67% higher than a year ago.
Stocks traded quietly higher Wednesday ahead of the Fed's policy statement at 2 p.m. ET.
The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all rose 0.1%. Nasdaq volume was tracking about 16% lower than Tuesday's level. NYSE volume fell 5%.

In the stock market today, FedEx (FDX) gapped above a flat-base buy point of 155.41. Shares jumped nearly 4% after the company reported a 37% rise in quarterly profit. Sales growth accelerated for the second straight quarter, rising 6% to $11.68 billion.

Meanwhile, IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group was one of the day's top performers, helped by strong earnings from Lennar (LEN). Shares gapped up and rose 6% after the company reported earnings and sales growth that topped expectations. Lennar was just below a buy point of 42.67.

Steel producers continued their recent string of outperformance. U.S. Steel (X) jumped 9% in strong volume after the company projected Q3 earnings significantly higher than the current consensus earnings-per-share estimates. Group peer Nucor (NUE) followed suit, gaining 3.5% in fast trade.

After a breakout over 117.35 Tuesday, railroad operator Kansas City Southern (KSU) extended gains, rising 3%. The company updated its 2014 earnings guidance Tuesday, saying it expects growth in the high teens. The Thomson Reuters consensus estimate is for annual earnings of $4.72 a share, up 19% from 2013.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) extended losses and fell further below its 50-day moving average. Shares lost 1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 traded in a tight range Monday, but the Nasdaq took a beating as profit-taking hit several recent highfliers.

The Nasdaq moved off lows but still fell 0.9%, hurt by weakness in Tesla Motors (TSLA). Shares dived 9% after Morgan Stanley reiterated its overweight rating but removed a 320 price target, basically saying the stock has gotten ahead of itself.
Biotechs also faced more selling pressure. High-quality names like Biogen Idec (BIIB), Alexion (ALXN) and Celgene (CELG) were all trading below their 50-day lines.
The S&P 500 fell fractionally, but the Dow rose 0.3% as investors turned defensive. Nasdaq volume was tracking sharply higher than Friday. NYSE volume fell a bit.
In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) added 0.4% after first-day pre-orders for the iPhone 6 topped 4 million, about double the number for the iPhone 5 two years ago.
Egg producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) extended gains after reclaiming its 10-week moving average last month. Shares rose 2% in heavy volume.

Big buyers came into steel producer Nucor (NUE) again on news it's buying Gallatin Steel for about $770 million. Shares rose 1%. Nucor is still in the early stages of clearing a long consolidation that started in November. IBD's Steel-Producers group now ranks No. 3 in IBD's 197 Industry Group Rankings, up from No. 28 three weeks ago and No. 40 six weeks ago.

Meanwhile, China-based e-commerce firm Alibaba is scheduled to price Thursday night and start trading Friday. The proposed price range is 60-66 a share, but it'll likely move higher due to overwhelming demand. Alibaba will trade under the symbol BABA.

In economic news, industrial production contracted unexpectedly in August, falling 0.1% vs. the consensus estimate for growth of 0.3%. Meanwhile, the latest reading from the Empire State Manufacturing Survey had better news. It soared to 27.54 in September from 14.69 in August. The consensus estimate was for a reading of 15.9.

Shares of U.S. Steel (X), AK Steel (AKS), Nucor (NUE), Steel Dynamics (STLD) and other steel stocks are gaining Thursday after the Commerce Department issued final findings that say steel producers from eight countries are dumping carbon and alloy steel plate imports in the U.S.The American steel industry is "under assault" from producers abroad that dump and subsidize their exports, said Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross in an emailed statement on the matter.Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Korea and Taiwan were named.Â On Tuesday, the Commerce Department said it had opened new anti-dumping duty and countervailing duty probes of aluminum foil from China."After a thorough investigation, the Department of Commerce has found that exporters of steel plate have received government subsidies and sold at unfairly low prices in the United States," said Ross in Thursday's statement. "The Trump administration is unequivocally committed to the vigorous enforcement of America's trade laws, including the finding of critical circumstances and the retroactive collection of duties when appropriate. We will ensure U.S. businesses and workers are treated fairly."The U.S. International Trade Commission will make final determinations on or around May 15, said the Commerce Department, and the U.S. Customs and Border Protection will be tasked with collecting cash deposits from American companies that import steel plates from the offending countries "equivalent to today's final margins on the value of these product shipments."Shares of U.S. Steel were up 3.3% on the stock market today, AK Steel jumped 2.3%, Nucor rose 0.55%, and Steel Dynamics added 0.6%. All four steel stocks are trading somewhat below their 50-day moving averages.RELATED:Steel Stocks Rebound On Trump Infrastructure Plans, M&A TalkÂ

Nucor (NUE) sparked higher on Thursday after the steel maker forecast massive gains in first-quarter earnings-per-share, joining U.S. Steel (X) in offering a better outlook forÂ market conditions.Â But Nucor's strong advance melted in the afternoon, while U.S. Steel and other rivals didn't join the advance.The IBD Leaderboard member rose 1.8% to 64.60 on the stock market today, fading into the close.Â Earlier, Nucor rose as high as 66, briefly clearing a 65.60 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Nucor rose 4.5% on Wednesday, rebounding from its 50-day line.Nucor expects first-quarter EPSÂ of $1.10 to $1.15, with the improvement from Q4 largely led by better results from itsÂ steel mills. Nucor earned 22 cents a year earlier, according to Thomson Reuters.Â Analysts expected 83 cents per share during the first quarter, according to Thomson Reuters."We are encouraged by the renewed growth in demand we are seeing in both the nonresidential construction and energy markets," NucorÂ said in a statement. "The heavy equipment markets remain weak. The automotive markets remain strong."IBD'S TAKE: Infrastructure plays have risen recently after President Trump vowed to spend "big" on things like roads and bridges, although stocks could slide if plans are delayed or altered as they make their way through Congress.Steel stocks surged following the election on the hopes that President Trump's infrastructure plans and economic protectionism would boost steel demand and prices.Nucor on Thursday noted that imports "continue to impact the U.S. steel industry." But it said recent trade cases "are helping to stop the flood of dumped and subsidized products from foreign producers, and are making sure that we can compete on a level-playing field."But for Thursday, at least, Nucor's forecast wasn't helping other steel plays, which had strong gains on Wednesday. U.S. Steel dipped 1% after surging 5.4% on Wednesday, rebounding off its 50-day line.Steel Dynamics (STLD) slipped 0.6%, reversing lower after retaking its 50-day line in the morning. Steel Dynamics rose 2.9% on Wednesday.Global steel giantÂ ArcelorMittal (MT) lost 0.8% following Wednesday's 5.9% jump.Even as steel makers are reporting better results, U.S. Steel, in reporting fourth-quarter earnings in January, cautioned that the path ahead could be rough."While we will benefit from improved market conditions, they continue to beÂ volatile and we must remain focused on improving the things that we can control," U.S. Steel CEO Mario Longhi said in a statement at that time.RELATED:Donald Trump: A Man Of Steel?Â

Stocks expanded their midday gains Wednesday after the Federal Reserve, as expected, hiked short-term interest rates by a quarter-point but hinted that it would continue to act prudently before engaging in further increases in the cost of money.Meanwhile, oil stocks got a much needed lift after getting slammed in recent days as crude oil futures rallied. West Texas Intermediate futures rose more than 2%, to $48.79 a barrel. Meanwhile, the metals, medical, heavy industrial and transport sectors also showed resilience.For instance, airline industry leader Southwest Air (LUV) is halting a seven-session losing streak and reversed off its lows, with a 2% gain, to 53.90, in fast turnover. Watch to see if the consumer- and business-spending play can climb back above its 50-day moving average. Shares are still up 8% year to date, better than the S&P 500's roughly 6% advance.Â Randgold Resources (GOLD) surged 3.3%, to 86.97, and is trying to retake its 50-day line. AngloGold Ashanti (AU) jumped 7.1%, to 10.54, but remains far depressed from its 52-week highs.Meanwhile, in the steel sector, Leaderboard name and industry top dog Nucor (NUE) rallied more than 3%, to 62.72, in low volume; watch to see if it can keep climbing and pierce through the top of its three-week handle with a 65.50 buy point.Nucor is seen growing Q1 profit by 230%, to 76 cents a share. Earnings have rebounded 28%, 43%, 144% and 63% vs. year-ago levels in the prior four quarters. A fifth sector, banking, is also regaining some lost ground; Bank of New York Mellon (BK) rose 0.6%, to 48.56, and is close to surpassing a 48.88 buy point within a nine-week cup-with-handle pattern.Small-cap issues are leading the stock market today with the Russell 2000 up 1.2%, vs. a 0.6% lift by the Nasdaq composite and 0.7% for the S&P 500.The Dow Jones industrials lagged, up 0.4%, but at least five of the 30 components rose at least 1 point or more, including Caterpillar (CAT), UnitedHealth Group (UNH), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and United Technologies (UTX). Â J&J has cleared a 122.60 early buy point within its long saucer construction. The left-side high of 126.07 also offers an entry point at 10 cents above that price.J&J has now risen slightly more than 5% past the early buy point. Be sure not to chase breakout stocks more than 5% past the proper entry. The reason: often a stock will pull back and try to shake out weak holders as it test support at or near the proper entry. IBD founder Bill O'Neil's study of the greatest market winners found that rarely does a leading stock market winner fall more than 7%-8% below the proper buy point in a cup, double bottom, flat base or other bullish pattern before a stock charges to new highs.Notice how, on the weekly chart, in six straight prior up weeks, J&J rose in above-average turnover in five of those weeks. That bodes well for the diversified medical products giant as it indicates surging demand for shares by mutual funds, hedge funds, insurers, banks and the like. J&J's Accumulation/Distribution Rating is now a sprightly A-; the proprietary grade goes from E (heavy distribution) to A+ (heavy accumulation).J&J's 66 RS Rating on a scale of 1 to 99 relects the big cap's long basing action and is sharply improved from as low as 26 just eight weeks ago. Among small and mid-cap names, focus on those with RS ratings of 80 or higher before they break out.Even with the move by the Fed to increase the fed funds rate to a 0.75%-1% target range, observers applauded the U.S. central bank's decision to maintain a careful and gradual approach to "normalizing" the bond markets."The weaker dollar itself is a reflection of the Fed's policy path," Quincy Krosby, market strategist at Prudential Financial, told IBD. "Markets see the Fed keeping a lid on the dollar and providing a bid for U.S. exporters, commodities and emerging markets."The U.S. dollar fell against both the euro and the Japanese yen.In the meantime, keep an eye out for the reaction by European equity markets on Wednesday's Dutch elections, which are being perceived as a test of Europeans' tolerance of immigrants, particularly from the Middle East. The Dutch elections could also have ramifications for the future of the eurozone. In June last year, Britons shocked the world by voting to leave the single-currency region.RELATED:Stock Market Today: Should You Sell These 7 Dow Industrials Components Now?How To Invest: Why The Base-On-Base Pattern Makes Money For InvestorsThe Top Market Sectors Today: See IBD's Smart Research Tables

Tense, late-stage maneuvering at the White House and the Capitol kept markets on edge straight to Friday's close, with major indexes ending mixed and the Dow Jones industrial average chalking up its worst week since the Nov. 8 presidential election.The Dow lost 0.3% Friday and 1.3% for the week. Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) took what were far-and-away the Dow's worst losses for the week, down 6.5% and 4%, respectively.Also in the Dow 30, Apple (AAPL) and McDonald's (MCD) each managed modest gains for the week and Nike (NKE), which on Wednesday dived more than 7% after a weak earnings report, on Friday trimmed its decline for the week to less than 3%.The S&P 500 sagged 0.1%, ending the week with a 1.3% loss â also its worst week since just before the election. Heavy engineering, steel and suppliers of construction materials took the S&P 500's heaviest hits on Friday. Vulcan Materials (VMC), Martin Marietta (MLM),Â Fluor (FLR) and Nucor (NUE) each dumped more than 2% in Friday's session. It's well-worth noting that all of those losses occurred in light trade.Micron Technology (MU) and Under Armour (UA) pegged the S&P 500's best gains.Micron spiked 7% as earnings rose to 90 cents a share, up from a penny in the year-ago quarter. Revenue soared 58%. But the industry took particular heart in Micron's Q3 outlook, which placed the midpoint of earnings guidance 61% above consensus views. Micron shares ended the week up 11% and at a new high, extended from a February rebound from 10-week support.Under Armour popped 4% following an upgrade to buy, from hold, by Jefferies. The stock suffered a 63% sell-off over the past 11 months, but the Jefferies note diagnosed the correction as having formed a bottom and, given market circumstances, "an inflection has formed and the buying (opportunity) is now." CAN SLIM investors can minimize risk by waiting for a proper base to form.The Nasdaq composite held its loss Friday to less than 0.1%, ending off 1.2% in its sharpest weekly slip since December. Micron topped the Nasdaq 100, with Western Digital (WDC), Tesla (TSLA), Cerner (CERN) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) all advancing 2% or more.Tesla chairman Elon Musk teased investors with tweets revealing new details regarding the company's upcoming Model 3, and more distant Model Y and Roadster vehicles. Tesla shares are five weeks into a consolidation â holding nice support at the stock's 10-week moving average, but it's slightly too deep to qualify as a flat base.Among IBD 50 stocks, China's TAL Education Group (TAL) jumped 3% Friday in its eighth straight daily advance. Shares are taking out new highs and are well-extended above a three-weeks-tight buy point of 83.97.BioTelemetry (BEAT) also gained 2%, narrowing its loss for the week to less than 3%. The stock bounced off its 10-week moving average on Thursday, but week volume nullified the move as a buying opportunity.RELATED:ObamaCare Repeal Vote Failure Threatens Tax Cuts â And Stock RallyChip Gear Makers Rise On Upbeat Micron OutlookStock Market Today: Do These 6 Chip Names Have A Shot At Big Gains In 2017?

President Trump's surprise election victory in November sparked a huge one-month rally in steel stocks as infrastructure spending became a likely administration priority. Since then, steel stocks have done littleÂ but consolidate despite weekly record highs in the general market. As such, their relative strength lines have declined dramatically, particularly during the first part of 2017. Last Thursday, steel makers soldâ¦

The reviews for President Trump's speech to Congress were strongly positive, from pundits, the public and, so far, investors. But doesÂ the speech really matter.The Dow Jones industrial averageÂ soared above 21,000 for the first time at Wednesday's opening bell, with the S&P 500 index andÂ Nasdaq composite also jumping to record highs. On Tuesday, the Dow industrials slipped 0.1% to end a string of 12 straight gains, while the S&P 500 index dipped 0.3%, the Nasdaq composite 0.6% and the small-cap Russell 2000 1.5%.If Trump is right that the stock market's impressive rise since his election has been driven by his policies, then what he didn't say in his speech matters a whole lot more than anything he did say. (Some of Wednesday's early gains may reflect shifting views and Treasury yields regarding a possible Federal Reserve rate hike at the March 14-15 meeting.)He didn't say how he would pay for or when he would advance his trillion-dollar infrastructure plan, a potential boon to Caterpillar (CAT), steel makers like U.S. Steel (X) andÂ Nucor (NUE), engineering and construction firms like Fluor (FLR) and construction aggregates suppliers like Vulcan Materials (VMC). Could last week's report that the plan will be delayed until 2018 be true? Not clear, but there's more reason to think so after Tuesday night.However, Nucor, U.S. Steel, Vulcan Materials, Caterpillar and Fluor were up 2%-3% in morning action.In any event, there appears to be a logjam of contentious issues blocking the road to more spending on highways and bridges. Trump managed to successfully turn the page after a rocky first five weeks in office in part because he stayed above the fray, declining to take any clear positions on the two issues that could largely determine whether his economic agenda rises or falls: ObamaCare and tax reform.Now he's about to enter a potentially hazardous stretch of his presidency in which he'll have to take firm policy stands that may divide his narrow governing majority in the Senate.On ObamaCare, the issue that Trump said must be addressed before tax reform, the clock is ticking for him to come up with a replacement that can unify Republicans, something that has proved impossible in the seven years since the law's passage. Humana (HUM) has already said it will exit the exchanges in 2018, while Aetna (AET) and Dow componentÂ UnitedHealth (UNH) have one foot out the door, and Anthem (ANTM) and Molina (MOH) won't commit to sticking around.Shares of UnitedHealth and other health insurers rose 1%-2% intraday.Come April, if Republicans haven't gotten their ducks in a row, insurers faced with setting premiums for 2018 will be in full panic mode and may start to pull the plug on their participation in the exchanges, leaving swaths of the country with no insurers for 2018.IBD'S TAKE:Â Despite growing doubts about the timing and size of President Trump's tax and spending stimulus plans, markets are pricing in higher odds of the Federal Reserve hiking rates again as early as this month.Â Tax reform doesn't look to be any easier. Trump wants to cut the corporate tax rate to 15% or 20%, but the House proposal for doing so depends on raising $1 trillion with a 20% tax on imports that's being fought by Wal-Mart (WMT) and the entire retail sector. Now General Motors (GM) is calling the tax "problematic," and a growing number of GOP senators oppose the idea.Trump stuck to vague generalities in his speech, saying, "We must create a level playing field for American companies and our workers."Who would oppose that? It's only when he arrives at a plan to pay for it â if not with a border tax then by taking away valued corporate tax subsidies â that the effort will turn into a mud fight.Trump is off to a slow start in clarifying how he will put his economic agenda into action. That's not surprising, because his agenda tackles major problems that have long defied solutions, but it should make investors nervous, regardless of what Trump said last night.RELATED:Â

Google says it will step up enforcement of advertising policies aimed at preventing ad placement next to inappropriate content after an uproar in the U.K. over government and branded ads appearing on video-sharing website YouTube.Google U.K. said in a blog on Friday that YouTube needs to do a better job in the wake of complaints that ads were placed alongside offensive content, such as videos promoting terrorism or anti-Semitism."With millions of sites in our network and 400 hours of video uploaded to YouTube every minute, we recognize that we don't always get it right," said Ronan Harris, Google's U.K. managing director, in the blog post. "In a very small percentage of cases, ads appear against content that violates our monetization policies. We promptly remove the ads in those instances, but we know we can and must do more."IBD'S TAKE: Marvell Technology (MRVL), Nucor (NUE) and Veeva Systems (VEEV) SystemsÂ are on IBD'sÂ Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) stock rose 0.3% to 872.37Â on the stock market today, hitting another all-time high, once again in below-average volume. Alphabet is still in range from an 867.10 buy point cleared this week.Google's announcement came after the U.K. government and the Guardian newspaper stepped up pressure on YouTube to police content on its platform,Â Bloomberg reported."We've begun a thorough review of our ads policies and brand controls, and we will be making changes in the coming weeks to give brands more control over where their ads appear across YouTube and the Google Display Network," added Harris in the blog.RELATED:Why You Need To Look At Apple, FANG Stocks Right NowIBM, Alibaba, Google Shine In Morgan Stanley Cloud Outlook

Shares of U.S. Steel (X), AK Steel (AKS) and other American steel producers climbed Friday after the U.S. International Trade Commission voted to impose antidumping duties on steel imports from seven countries, a report said.The commission will impose duties on India, South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Taiwan, Turkey, Ukraine and Vietnam. But it exempted the Philippines and Thailand, Reuters said.U.S. steelmakers complained to federal officials in 2013 that cheap imports were driving down prices as imports of pipes used by the oil and natural gas industry surged on the shale oil fracking boom.The Economic Policy Institute (EPI) said this May that cheap steel imports were putting 500,000 U.S. jobs at risk."The U.S. steel industry is facing its worst import crisis in more than a decade," the nonprofit think tank said, adding that in the aftermath of the Great Recession, "the open and large U.S. market became the prime target for the massive excess supply stemming from this excess capacity."The EPI estimated that global excess steel capacity had reached 500 million metric tons, more than twice the volume of excess capacity in the last steel import crisis, which followed the Asian financial crisis more than a decade ago.U.S. Steel shares were up 2.3% in midafternoon trading on the stock market today, Friday.The Pittsburgh-based steel producer has an 89 IBD Composite Rating, which means that its stock has outperformed 89% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.AK Steel has also seen strong growth recently as U.S. manufacturers continue to recover. Its share price has surged about 74% from a May 3 low of 5.97 and was trading at 10.36 midday Friday, up 3.6%.Among other U.S. companies in the Steel-Producers group, ranked a strong 32 on IBD's list of 197 industries, SunCoke Energy Partners (SXCP) and Nucor (NUE) rose fractionally, while Ampco-Pittsburgh (AP) was unchanged.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Accountability often comes with a stigma: You're to blame if something goes wrong. That's not how it should work. It's about making sure that people follow up. "It's really talking about, 'Can I count on you?'" said Greg Bustin, a Dallas-based management consultant.Here's how to make sure that you can count on your staff.â¢ Define. Set your firm's values so that staffers are clear about what's important. Then they'll know to always be honest, on time or helpful to customers. Bustin, who wrote the book "Accountability: The Key to Driving a High-Performance Culture," worked with one company that valued integrity, but its meetings started 15 minutes late. "You can't have values that you don't treat as values," he told IBD. "That's where it all starts."â¢ Be clear. Tell people exactly what you expect from them. Doing so builds confidence in them, Bustin says, because they know what their goal is and how to get there. The leader's job is to set the expectations. "It's really hard to hold someone accountable if they don't know what to do," he said.â¢ Change your thoughts. Accountability is a way of thinking, says Linda Galindo, a Park City, Utah-based accountability expert who co-wrote "Where Winners Live: Sell More, Earn More, Achieve More Through Personal Accountability."Be accountable by taking ownership of the results before you start a task. You'll know that you're responsible for the outcome.â¢ Take charge. You'll always have excuses. Maybe the weather slowed deliveries or your vendors fell behind, but it's still your job to get things done. Think ahead about what can fail; anticipate solutions before you need them. "Take ownership for all of it, even if you can't control it," Galindo said.â¢ Measure. Track your progress, Bustin says. Steel maker Nucor (NUE) stays on top of safety, quality and output metrics, and posts them so workers know where they stand in those areas. "Tell people, 'We're not tracking to punish you; we're tracking so we can make better decisions,'" Bustin said.â¢ Set boundaries. You need rules for those who fail to perform up to snuff, Galindo says.If someone is late to a meeting, explain why punctuality is important and say that you'll trust him to make it promptly next time. Take action if it continues. That'll get others to sharpen up."You absolutely want the culture to be such that people show up on time anyway," she said.â¢ Be fair. When you have to dish out punishment, handle the task objectively. Even if your best salesperson is easily beating monthly goals, if he keeps getting reports in late, tell him that you'll reject them next time. If it keeps up, be prepared to let him leave.This approach includes managers. "You want to get people to not compare themselves to others in how they're punished," Galindo said. Treating them all the same will help them avoid comparisons.â¢ Reward. Nudge people toward being accountable for doing what they said by rewarding them. Nucor pays for performance with a system that shows its staff what success looks like, Bustin said: "Then people understand, 'Here's what it means to me.'"â¢ Find the payoff. Show others how important it is that they live up to what they say, Galindo says. Spell out how much their ability to be accountable adds to results.â¢ Share the power. The boss needn't do all the enforcing. Peers can do it too, Bustin said: "If someone is in position to hold a colleague accountable, that's a lot more powerful" than a boss doing it.

The Federal Reserve raised interest rates but didn't signal that it plans to be more aggressive, sending stocks slightly higher and bond yields sharply lower. Intel (INTC) is buying Mobileye (MBLY), putting its chips on self-driving cars, as Tesla (TSLA) raises cash for its big bet on the Model 3.Â Oracle (ORCL) and Adobe Systems (ADBE) reported strong cloud revenue. Snap (SNAP) continued to tumble to fresh post-IPO lows, but other new issues had strong debuts.The Nasdaq composite rose 0.7% for the week, briefly hitting an all-time high Friday afternoon, helped by Oracle as well as the ongoing strength of Apple (AAPL) and the FANG internet stocks.. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.1% and the S&P 500 index 0.2%, as the Fed raised rates but didn't signal a faster pace of hikes going forward. Â The 10-year Treasury yield tumbled from recent peaks on the "dovish rate hike," pressuring bank stocks such as the Dow's JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS). Homebuilders rallied on the lower yields, while steel stocks climbed on bullish earnings forecasts.The Federal Reserve gave financial markets what they wanted, hiking rates a quarter-point, as expected, but stuck to its plan forÂ two more hikes this year and three next year. Policymakers' recent hawkish signals had markets bracing for a quicker ramp-up. The news was great for homebuilders like Lennar (LEN) and Toll Brothers (TOL), since it means that mortgage rates may stabilize for a time after their recent run-up, helping boost the spring selling season. Financials like Bank of America (BAC) and Goldman Sachs (GS), which had been pushing higher on hopes for faster rate hikes that can help lift net interest margins, took a breather after the Fed news.RELATED:Chip giant Intel (INTC) announced a deal to buy Mobileye (MBLY), a maker of advanced driver assistance systems, for $15.3 billion. Analysts described the deal as a defensive acquisition for Intel to compete against Nvidia (NVDA), which has been scoring numerous partnerships to supply the artificial-intelligence processing power for self-driving cars. Nvidia's latest partnerships are with auto parts supplier Bosch to bring self-driving cars to the masses and with truck maker Paccar (PCAR) to develop autonomous trucks.Tesla announced that it would sell $750 million in convertible debt and $250 million in stock. With underwriter options, Tesla will likely raise $1.15 billion. That's less than some analysts had expected after CEO Elon Musk warned that the Model 3 would push cash levels "close to the edge." Tesla rose on the funding news after soaring on a report that the company will release a small SUV next year. Tesla shares rose 7.3% for the week.RELATED:Oracle reported fiscal Q3 earnings that cruised past estimates as the software giant's transition to a cloud-based model picks up momentum. Oracle, which three years ago began a concerted push into cloud computing, said its software-as-a-service and platform-as-a-service non-GAAP revenue jumped 85% to $1.1 billion, as total cloud revenue reached $1.2 billion, up 62%. Oracle's traditional software licensing business fell 16% as the company transitions.Oracle leapt 6% on Thursday, hitting an all-time intraday high.RELATED:Digital media and marketing software firm Adobe Systems (ADBE) posted better-than-expected sales and earnings for its fiscal first quarter and gave Q2 targets ahead of forecasts. Adobe stock jumped to record high territory on the news. In Q1, Adobe earned 94 cents a share excluding items, up 42% year over year, on sales of $1.68 billion, up 22%. Analysts were looking for 87 cents and $1.65 billion. For Q2, Adobe guided analyst estimates slightly higher.Adobe shares soared to a record high Friday.RELATED:MuleSoft (MULE) popped 46% in Friday's trading debut after pricing its IPO late Thursday at 17, above its upwardly revised range of 14-16. Outdoor apparel maker Canada Goose (GOOS) popped 26% in Thursday's debut and kept rising Friday.Â Oilfield services provider ProPetro (PUMP) priced low but rose 3.6% in its debut. The hope has been that the recent IPO of Snapchat operator Snap will lead to a burst of new issues. But after a strong IPO pricing at 17, a 44% first-day gain and a record high of 29.44 the next day, Snap shares have plunged to post-IPO lows, tumbling 11.5% for the week.RELATED:Crude oil prices rose 0.6% to $48.78 a barrel for the week after a big seven-session sell-off.Â The International Energy Agency said if OPEC keeps its production levels steady until June, the market would see a deficit of 500,000 barrels per day in the first half of the year. Right on cue, theÂ Energy Information Administration reported a surprise 237,000-barrel drop in weekly U.S. crude stockpiles last week. Earlier, Saudi Arabia said it raised its crude output to 10.011 million barrels per day in February, up 2.7% from January, but still under the target agreed to under a production-cut deal.RELATED:Delta Air Lines (DAL), United Airlines (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL) got dinged early in the week after Winter Storm Stella forced thousands of flight cancellations. But the airlines got a potential break after federal judges halted key provisions in President Trump's travel ban. In between, United raised its full-year capacity outlook. That gives travelers more options, but the expansion carries risks of overestimating demand and a competitive response from rival airlines. United last month said it would add service to 31 new destinations to serve areas that connect to its airport hubs. Meanwhile, Alaska Air Group (ALK) this week stepped up its offerings on the West Coast. United stock slid 7.7% for the week, while Delta lost 5.1% and American 2.9%.RELATED:Tesaro (TSRO) stock crashed Tuesday after AstraZeneca (AZN) posted strong ovarian cancer trial results, also boosting Clovis Oncology (CLVS) stock to a 16-month high. AstraZeneca's Lynparza met its primary endpoint, hitting a median 19.1 months of progression-free survival vs. 5.5 months for patients on the placebo.Â In a similar trial, Tesaro's niraparib delayed reoccurrence of ovarian cancer for 21 months.Â A best-case review found Lynparza delayed ovarian cancer's return by a median 30.2 months.Meanwhile, Valeant Pharmaceuticals stock plunged to an eight-year low after William Ackman sold Pershing Square's entire stake in the ailing drugmaker. Pershing held 8% of Valeant, or about 27.2 million shares.Amgen announced its cholesterol drug Repatha trimmed the risk of heart attack, stroke and cardiovascular death, but not as much asÂ some had hoped. Amgen shares fell 6.4% Friday. Regeneron (REGN), Medicines Co. (MDCO) and Esperion (ESPR) also tumbled.RELATED:Shares of hospitals and Medicaid-focused insurers slid following Monday's late-day Congressional Budget Office score showing House Speaker Paul Ryan's ObamaCare repeal bill would slash Medicaid funding by one-third and leave 24 million more Americans uninsured.Despite political blowback for RyanCare from both moderate and conservative Republicans, and uncertainty over the bill's chances, a cloud remained over the hospital group. Through Thursday trading, Tenet Healthcare (THC) was off sharply for the week whileÂ HCA Holdings (HCA) also slid. Insurers bounced back,Â with Molina Healthcare (MOH), Centene (CNC) and Anthem (ANTM) closing the week with slim gains.RELATED:China social networking company YY (YY) reported Q4 earnings beat estimates, but delivered a first-quarterÂ outlook below consensus views. YY reported adjusted earnings of $1.40 per American depositary receipt, topping the consensus estimate of $1.03. Revenue rose 31% in local currency to $357.8 million, fueled by users who pay for its live streaming services. YY shares initially reversed lower on the Q1 outlook, but rallied to end the week up 8.9%. Meanwhile Momo (MOMO), which recently reported booming revenue from live streaming video, continued to rally for fresh highs.Nucor (NUE) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) both raised first-quarter earnings guidance well above views, sending both steel stocks higher.Â

Infrastructure stocks including equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT), U.S. Steel (X) and construction materials supplier Vulcan Materials (VMC) all were buoyed in early Wednesday trading by optimism over President Trump's speech to Congress last night.Trump didn't offer details but reiteratedÂ his plan to invest $1 trillion in new roads, bridges, tunnels, airports and railways via a combination of public and private funds.Even as the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index surged to record highs on the stock market today, infrastructure stocks generally outperformed the major averages. Dow component Caterpillar closed 2% higher, U.S. Steel rallied 2.5%, Nucor (NUE) rose 2.3%, construction and engineering giant Fluor (FLR) added 2.2%, Vulcan Materials gained 3.1% and Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) rose 2.9%.Caterpillar, U.S. Steel and other infrastructure stocks were big winners after the presidential election, but have been up and down in recent weeks, looking for clarity about what Trump will do, and when.IBD'S TAKE: A big boost in federal infrastructure spending would be huge forÂ infrastructure stocks, but here's why construction industry CEOs are bullish about their outlook even if President Trump doesn't come through."The time has come for a new program of national rebuilding," Trump said, though exactly what "time" he has in mind for legislation is unclear. One report out last week said that passage of an infrastructure bill might wait until 2018, and it generally takes 18 months for new funds to start flowing in a major way."There have been mixed signals from the White House about how big a priority infrastructure is for the administration," wrote Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Washington analyst Brian Gardner wrote on Wednesday. "We think infrastructure spending could get squeezed out by competing agenda items such as health care and tax reform."RELATED:Â
