Nucor shares fell 7% last week, Steel Dynamics 1%, while Worthington and U.S. Steel (X) shed 4%.Nucor and U.S. Steel fell fractionally during Monday's regular session while Steel Dynamics edged higher.RELATED:Steel Dynamics Is Second Steel Maker To Warn On Profit In 2 Days

Nucor (NUE) gave weak fourth-quarter guidance Thursday, initially hitting steel stocks, which have been big winners following Donald Trump's election victory.Nucor sees fourth-quarter earnings of 30 cents to 35 cents per share, down from 88 cents in the third quarterÂ and 46 cents a year ago. Analysts are expecting 51 cents.The company said theÂ sequential decline is "due to lower margins in the steel mills segment."But Nucor is more bullish about 2017."Market conditions for the steel mills segment have been marked by volatility in sales prices and demand during 2016," the steel maker said in a release "Looking ahead to 2017, we are optimistic about continued improvement in market conditions. Prices have increased throughout the fourth quarter for our sheet, bar, structural and plate mills."Nucor fell as low as 61.01, but rallied to close down just 0.3% at 62.87Â on the stock market today. United States Steel (X), Steel Dynamics (STLD) andÂ AK Steel (AKS) losses to close up 0.9%, 1.4% and 1.7%, respectively. Global steel giantÂ ArcelorMittal (MT) fell 0.4%, but off session lows.After the market close, Nucor agreed to pay $335 million forÂ electrical-conduit maker Republic Conduit from Tenaris (TS), as the company continues its expansion in the pipe-and-tube market.Steel companies have rallied on President-elect Donald Trump's agenda. Trump plans tax cuts and invest $1 trillion in infrastructure projects including highways, bridges, airports and rails that require massive amounts of steel. Steel makers also might benefit from increased anti-dumping levies on Chinese steel and other "America first" trade policies.IBD'S TAKE: Steel makers aren't the only companies to see a Trump bump, theÂ banking industry has also rallied after the election and Trump. Here's a look at what stocks could drive a potential bull market in the Trump era.RELATED:Â Steel Plays Surge To New Highs On Price Strength, Trump Pledges

Steel Dynamics (STLD) issued weakÂ fourth-quarter profit guidanceÂ Friday, a day after Nucor (NUE) gaveÂ its own warning.Steel Dynamics sees Q4 adjusted earnings of 40 cents to 44 cents per share, the midpoint below the 44 cents analysts forecast.The companyÂ said Q4 steel operations are expected to "decrease significantly" vs. Q3Â on "lower shipments and metal spread compression. But it also said flat roll steel selling values and customer order activity " improved meaningfully" in November and December and expects the trend to continue into 2017.On Thursday, Nucor said it sees Q4 EPS of 30 to 35 cents, down from 88 cents in Q3Â and 46 cents a year ago. Analysts had expectedÂ 51 cents. But Nucor pared big early losses to close down 0.3%, though its was the stock's sixth straight retreat. Steel Dynamics, United States Steel (X) and AK Steel (AKS) also closed Thursday higher.But steel makers had a tougher time with a second straight warnings.Steel Dynamics shares fell 1.85% to 36.68 on the stock market today. Nucor shares were down 3.5%. U.S. SteelÂ sank 3.2% to 34.70. AK Steel declined 1.8% to 10.38. Global steel giantsÂ ArcelorMittal (MT) retreated 3%.Steel companies' post-Donald Trump election rally has cooled over the past week. During the election, Trump touted plans to investÂ $1 trillion in infrastructure projectsÂ  that require massive amounts of steel. Morgan Stanley said this week that Trump's plans could boost domestic steel demand by 20%. Trump's protectionist instincts, notably in regard to China, also could boost U.S. steel makers.IBD'S TAKE: Steel makers aren't the only companies to see a Trump bump, theÂ banking industry has also rallied after the election.Steel Dynamics said theÂ sequential decline is "due to lower margins in the steel mills segment" but it is also bullish on 2017.RELATED:Â Steel Plays Surge To New Highs On Price Strength, Trump Pledges

Two regional manufacturing gauges jumped in December, data showed Thursday, reflecting increased "animal spirits" for business and investors following President-elect Donald Trump's victory. Meanwhile, home builder sentiment skyrocketed to a boom-era levels despite rising mortgage rates. Consumer inflation jumped to a two-year high in November while weekly jobless claims fell.The Philadelphia Federal Reserve manufacturing index popped to a two-year high of 21.5 vs. 7.6 in November. The New York Fed's Empire State manufacturing index rose by 7.5 points to 9, the strongest since April.Looking ahead, the Philly Fed's outlook gauge nearly doubled to 52.6 from 29.3, hitting the highest since January 2015. The Empire State's future gauge was the best in nearly five years.Higher corporate sentiment could spur more hiring and investment, the latter of which has been poor throughout the current economic expansion.Separately, Markit's flash December reading for U.S. manufacturing nudged higher to a 21-month high.However, many industrial companies are struggling. Nucor (NUE) warned on Q4 profit Thursday morning, initially hitting other steel makers such as U.S. Steel (X) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) on the stock market today. But Nucor pared losses while U.S. Steel turned flat and Steel Dynamics closed higher. Steel stocks have been big postelection winners on hopes for tax cuts, infrastructure spending â and protectionism under a Trump administration.United Technologies (UTX) issued a cautious 2017 outlook late Wednesday, with shares down 1% on Thursday, after undercuttingÂ a recent buy point in the prior session.But machinery firm Nordson (NDSN) climbed 3.2% on Thursday after soaring to a record intraday high Wednesday on strong quarterly results.The National Association of Home Builders' Housing Market Index shot up by 7 points to 70, the highest since 2005, near the peak of the housing boom. Economists had expected 63. Readings over 50 signal confidence. Mortgage rates have soared to two-year highs following Trump's election on expectations for faster economic growth, higher inflation and more Federal Reserve hikes. But builders were cheered by the prospect that the real estate mogul will be in the White House.Shares of Toll Bros. (TOL), D.R. Horton (DHI) and LGI Homes (LGIH) initially rose but 0.6%, 2.1% and 3%, respectively.The consumer price index rose 0.2% in November, the Labor Department said. That's in line with views and follows October's 0.4% gain. It was the fourth straight monthly increase, with housing and gasoline fueling November's advance. Core CPI, which excludes food and energy, climbed 0.2%.Year over year, consumer prices climbed 1.7%, the most in two years. Core inflation edged up to 2.2%.The Fed has a 2% inflation target, though it's favorite price gauge, the core PCE deflator, is still not at that level. Fed chief Janet Yellen and some policymakers have hinted at a willingness to let the economy run a little hot in the short run.But the Fed did raise rates on Wednesday and forecast three hikes in 2017.Jobless claims fell by 4,000 to a three-week-low 254,000 in the week ended Dec. 10, Labor said. That was in line with analyst estimates and near longtime lows.Claims have stayed below 300,000 for 93 straight weeks, the longest stretch since 1970.

Federal Reserve policymakers, the air traffic controllers of the economy, are likely to signal clear running room for economic growthÂ â and, by extension, the Trump stock-market rallyÂ â when they telegraph their views on Wednesday.A quarter-point rate hike, just the second interest-rate increase in a decade, is a mere formality at this point, with markets pricing in a 97% chance. What matters to markets is what the Fed has to sayÂ about the rate-hiking outlook for 2017 and beyond via Fed members' quarterly economic projections released along with the 2 p.m. ET policy statement and Chair Janet Yellen's post-meeting press conference.When Fed policymakers last detailed their economic projectionsÂ in September, they signaled two more quarter-point rate hikes in the coming year and three additional hikes in 2018. Any indication that the Fed isÂ getting antsy about inflation pressures and speeding up this timetable wouldn't go down well with markets. But there are someÂ big reasons to doubt that policymakers will take such a hawkish turn right on the heels of the election.The Fed meeting comes as economicÂ growth is on the upswing and the IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index is at a 10-year high. Major stock indexes have surged to record highs amid hopes for President-elect Donald Trump's agenda of tax cuts, an infrastructure-spending binge and regulatory relief. Shares of industrial companies like Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) and steel maker Nucor (NUE) have outperformed, as have financials like Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM).Yet there's still a great deal of uncertainty about what Republicans will be able to pass. With 52 GOP senators, Republicans will have to overcome a Democratic filibuster by passing tax legislation via reconciliation, which requires budget neutrality beyond 10 years.IBD'S TAKE:Â As the Trump agenda emerges, read IBD Leaderboard and The Big Picture each day to see how market leaders are performing, to find breakout candidates for your watchÂ list, and to Â get the best assessment of whether the stock market has more running room.Â Federal Reserve Board governors and regional bank presidents have continually lowered their economic projections over the past year, so a sudden hawkish shift could renew charges leveled by Trump during the campaign that policymakers had a political agenda all along.At her post-meeting press conference on Sept. 21, Yellen said, "We found the economy has a bit more running room," thanks to more people being attracted into the labor force.Â While the November employment report showed the jobless rate falling to 4.6% from 4.9%, it's unlikely that the Fed will make too much of a single month's data point in the rather volatile household survey.Yellen has urged caution on raising ratesÂ for much of the past year, warning that the Fed has much more leeway to fight inflation than to stimulate the economy with its key interest rate still near zero."Policymakers have been arguing for fiscal policy to take the baton to boost growth," wrote Jefferies economists Ward McCarthy and Thomas Simons. "While fiscal policy appears to be on the way, the Fed will wait until fiscal plans have been implemented before altering the outlook for monetary policy in a meaningful way."At least as far as the Fed is concerned, Trump is likely to get a honeymoon, but it may not be a long one, writes Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics."Chair Yellen will be able to dodge questions on the inflation risks posed by fiscal loosening at Wednesday's press conference, simply by pointing out that no legislation has yet been proposed, let alone passed," Shepherdson wrote. "But the question will have to be addressed directly by the spring, at the latest."For now, Yellen is likely toÂ take the same tack as she did in her testimony to Congress the week after the election, gently advising members to take into account the concerning fiscal outlook when they formulate tax and spending policies."With the debt-to-GDP ratio at around 77%, there's not a lot of fiscal space should a shock to the economy occur, an adverse shock that did require fiscal stimulus," she said.RELATED:As Trumponomics Cheers Wall Street, Economists FretWhat's Really Doable In Trump's First 100 Days?

For now, investors still aren't too worried about the Fed having to hike rates too fast in 2017 to avoid an overheating.While auto sales were apparently boosted by discounts, the bullish consumer and investor mood since the election may have helped. Ford saw double-digit gains in SUV and pickup sales more than offset weakness in small-car sales.Better days for the industrial side of the economy are expected in 2017. Commodity prices have been on the rise and steelmakers such as Nucor (NUE) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) are expecting to get a lift from President-elect Trump's infrastructure plans, and perhaps various protectionist policies. On the other hand, a stronger dollar will be a slight negative for U.S. producers.RELATED:GM, Ford Shares Jump As Trucks, SUVs Lead November Sales

The Dow continued its ascent toward 20,000 near midday Thursday as American Express (AXP), Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) led the charge.Apple (AAPL), meanwhile, drew closer to a 118.79 flat-base entry, although most of its recent gains have come in average or below-average turnover.The Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all showed gains of around 0.6%. Small caps outperformed with the Russell 2000 up 1.2%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking about 20% higher than Wednesday's levels.In the stock market today, Dow component United Technologies (UTX) held up well despite issuing a lukewarm 2017 outlook late Wednesday. Shares lost 0.5% as the stock trades just below a 109.52 cup-with-handle buy point.Gold continued to lose its luster. After falling 1.5% Wednesday, SPDR Gold Trust (GLD) shed anotherÂ  1% Thursday.Steel stocks weakened after Nucor (NUE) guided Q4 earnings below expectations. Shares of Nucor fell 3% early but recovered for a loss of just over 1%. Nucor is still holding comfortably above a 57.18 entry.In economic news, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index soared to a two-year high, rising to 21.5 in December vs. a reading of 7.6 in November. Meanwhile, consumer prices were tame in November, but year over year, consumer prices climbed 1.7%, the most in two years. Adobe Systems (ADBE) added 0.4% to 106.23 as it works on a base with a 111.19 buy point. Earnings are due after the close. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were poised Monday afternoon to end a six-session win streak, unwinding part of the Trump rally at least for a day.The small-cap Russell 2000, which has led the rally, dropped 1.2%. The Nasdaq fell 0.7%, while the S&P 500 trimmed 0.1%. However, the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was running about 10% higher on the NYSE and 11% lower on the Nasdaq.The day's big gainers included oil stocks and utilities. On the downside, the groups favored by the rally that appears to have come with President-elect Donald Trump â steel, cement and bank shares â were down.No market can go straight up, but two stocks in the Dow haveÂ taken a stab at it recently. Goldman Sachs (GS) rose about 40% since its October breakout before correcting 2% Monday afternoon. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) advanced almost 25% since bouncing off its 50-day line in early November and fell 1% intraday Thursday.The Dow is trailing the small-cap indexes but has outperformed the S&P 500 and Nasdaq since the Election Day close. The Dow is up 8% vs. 5% for the S&P 500 and 4% for the Nasdaq.Among the cement plays, Dallas-based Eagle Materials (EXP) is testing its short term 10-day moving average. Short-term investors will sometimes sell if a stock violates that line after an advance from a breakout.Eagle MaterialsÂ rose as much as 13% afterÂ an opening price gap up Nov. 9 but fell 2.6% Monday afternoon. The stock is trying to cross and hold above the 100 price level. The 100 priceÂ area could develop into a support or resistance level.Steel stocks were down, with several testing the 10-day lines. They included Nucor (NUE), Steel Dynamics (STLD) and United States Steel (X).Stocks have gotten extended, and many leaders are well above the traditional 50-day and 200-day lines. Individual investors may wish that leaders would come down and test the 50-day line to create follow-on buy areas, but wishes don't always come true. If the stock market resumes its bullish thrust in the days ahead, then the 50-day line is unlikely to come into play.On Tuesday and Wednesday, the Federal Reserve will meet. The Fed is expected to increase interest rates. However, market watchers will be looking for clues regarding future rate hikes.RELATED:The Fed Won't Rain On Trump's Stock ParadeOil Deal Could Send Crude to $60 By January
It's good to be a steel maker these days, and the SPDR S&P Metals & Mining (XME) ETF can be

thankful for that.Five of the largest components of the exchange traded fund are steel makers, comprising about 28% of the portfolio's weighting. Moreover, 58% of the fund is concentrated in steel companies.While most metal and mining stocks have been surging in November, the steel industry is setting the pace. IBD's steel producers industry group is up about 34% so far this month and the specialty alloys group is up more than 25%. By comparison, mining stocks are lagging. IBD's metal ores group is up about 20% in November and the gold and silver mining group is down more than 12%.Copper mining, which has been another hot industry as the metal rallies, comprises 5% of the fund's holdings. Gold makes up 9% and silver nearly 7%.Steel, one of the hardest alloys on the planet, finds itself in a favored market position since the Nov. 8 election. President-elect Donald Trump says he wants to boost spending on infrastructure projects, and steel will be needed to build and fix highways, bridges and airports. Trump also campaigned in support of trade tariffs, and steel mills may benefit from that too.Indeed, the main thrust of the steel rally came the day after the election.Chart readers would find plenty to like by reviewing the major holdings of the ETF, which is a popular vehicle for investing in that sector. (Its average daily volume is nearly 5 million shares a day.)Nucor (NUE) broke out the day after the election and is already extended from a 57.18 buy point. AK Steel Holding (AKS), the single largest piece of the fund, broke out the next day and is up more than 25% from its entry. The stock, though, remains under 10 a share after plummeting in the 2008-09 bear market.U.S. Steel (X) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) are others that are up sharply in less than two weeks from their breakouts. Reliance Steel & Aluminum (RS) broke out just Tuesday.The ETF itself broke out Nov. 14 past a 29.33 buy point and has become slightly extended from that entry. For the year, SPDR S&P Metals & Mining has more than doubled in price. Precious and industrial metals can go into prolonged bull and bear markets. The ETF was in a nearly five-year bear market until it bottomed in January.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. ArcelorMittal (MT) missed analyst first-quarter targets, but shares rose sharply after CEO Lakshmi Mittal offered hope to investors, confirming that it's on target to meet full-year goals.

The world's largest steel maker by revenue said before the market opened Friday that steel markets are stabilizing, it's sharply reduced its debt, and efforts to focus on higher-margin segments are yielding results.

"Economic conditions remain challenging but our performance in the quarter reflects the results of the management action we have taken to confront the effects of the financial crisis," Mittal said in a press statement.
The Netherlands-based company's sales fell 13% to $19.75 billion during the quarter. Analysts expected $20.96 billion.
ArcelorMittal recorded a 21-cent net per-share loss, reversing a 1-cent per share profit a year ago.
For the full year, the company reiterated that it expects at least $7.1 billion in core profits, measured by earnings before costs from interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of goodwill.
EBITDA was $1.57 billion last quarter, down from $2.1 billion in the year-earlier period but above projections of $1.32 billion.
After rising as much as 7% in heavy volume early Friday, ArcelorMittal shares were up 2.2% in late morning stock market trading.

After trading in a narrow range for most of 2012, its stock price hit a 17.99 high on Jan. 23 then plunged 38% to 11.5 on April 18. After Friday's action, it was up 18% from the April bottom and trading above its 50-day average for the first time since early February.
Its stock still had a dismal IBD Composite Rating of 2, meaning 98% of all stocks have outperformed it recently on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
That's partly a reflection of the poor performance of the steel producers group, ranked a cellar-dwelling 186 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups.

Among other steel companies in the group, Nucor (NUE) was down 1%, U.S. Steel (X) was down less than 1%, Luxembourg-based Tenaris (TS) slid 0.7% and small, highly-rated SunCoke Energy Partners (SXCP) dipped fractionally.ArcelorMittal (MT) missed analyst first-quarter targets, but shares rose sharply after CEO Lakshmi Mittal offered hope to investors, confirming that it's on target to meet full-year goals.The world's largest steel maker by revenue said before the market opened Friday that steel markets are stabilizing, it's sharply reduced its debt, and efforts to focus on higher-margin segments are yielding results."Economic conditions remain challenging but our performance in the quarter reflects the results of the management action we have taken to confront the effects of the financial crisis," Mittal said in a press statement.The Netherlands-based company's sales fell 13% to $19.75 billion during the quarter. The domestic energy production boom fueled by fracking and new discoveries is turning trade into a bigger boost for the economy.
A sharp improvement in the petroleum trade balance helped shrink the overall deficit by 21% in December to $38.5 billion, the smallest in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said Friday.
The trade data suggest Q4's gross domestic product will be revised to show an expansion vs. the initial 0.1% contraction.

Petroleum exports rose 9% vs. November to a record $11.6 billion â up 1,056% from December 1999. Petroleum imports fell 11% to $30.3 billion and were down 21% from a year earlier, as greater U.S. energy output cut demand for foreign supplies.
Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, also has unlocked more natural gas, which is now more attractive to U.S. industry as a cheap energy source and chemical feedstock.
Cheap Energy Edge
That, along with other factors like rising foreign wages, is spurring a return of some manufacturing back to the U.S. to further tilt trade to its advantage.

Dow Chemical (DOW) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) are building chemical plants in the U.S. while Nucor (NUE) plans to make more steel here using natural gas. Potash (POT) is reopening an ammonia plant closed in 2003.
"We're at a very interesting inflection point in the U.S. trade balance," said Robert Dye, chief economist at Comerica.

In addition to the steel and chemical industries, cheap U.S. oil and natural gas will benefit a variety of other energy-intensive sectors, Dye added. He has even heard talk of "reshoring" toilet manufacturing, which requires a lot of heat to bake ceramics.

The drilling process itself will be a long-term economic driver as well, even though the number of rigs has eased, Dye said. Extraction activity will continue to require steel and equipment, pro vide high-paying jobs and boost tax revenue for governments.

Increased domestic oil production should keeping holding down imports too. In November, the International Energy Agency predicted fracking will help the U.S. become the world's top oil producer in the next several years before ceding the title again in 20 years.

The IEA sees U.S. production of 10 million barrels per day in 2015 growing to 11.1 million in 2020. It expects output from current No. 1 Saudi Arabia to be 10.9 million barrels a day in 2015 but dip to 10.6 million by 2020.
The agency forecasts U.S. output will drop again to 9.2 million bpd in 2035, with Saudi production rising to 12.3 million bpd.
But the petroleum export boom has less to do with fracking and more to do with U.S. refineries, said James Williams, an energy analyst at WTRG Economics.
U.S. laws generally bar domestic crude from being sold over seas. Refined products like diesel are fair game, and most crude that export-oriented U.S. refineries use is imported, he said.

But those refineries are more efficient at processing heavy crude, which has been more prevalent in recent discoveries, than foreign rivals are, he said. That has made U.S. refined products increasingly competitive.
For all of 2012, exports of fuel oil climbed 14% to $60.2 billion, and exports of other petroleum products rose 4% to $57 billion.

Domestic oil output "is more relevant to the reduction of imports of crude," Williams said. "But it's improving our balance of trade."The domestic energy production boom fueled by fracking and new discoveries is turning trade into a bigger boost for the economy.A sharp improvement in the petroleum trade balance helped shrink the overall deficit by 21% in December to $38.5 billion, the smallest in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said Friday.The trade data suggest Q4's gross domestic product will be revised to show an expansion vs. the initial 0.1% contraction.Petroleum exports rose 9% vs. November to a record $11.6 billion â up 1,056% from December 1999. Illinois Tool Works (ITW) said fourth-quarter earnings and revenue rose slightly on growth in North American markets. The diversified manufacturer said earnings rose 1% to 89 cents per share, in line with analyst estimates. Revenue rose 2% to $4.2 billion, but fell short of estimates for $4.3 billion. Illinois Tool shares were down nearly 3% intraday Tuesday. Revenue from theâ¦
Nucor (NUE) issued a warning on its second-quarter profit on Wednesday as a deluge of cheap steel imports from Turkey and Russia have put pressure on prices.

The No. 2 U.S. steel company sees Q2 earnings of 35-40 cents per share, well below analyst expectations of 56 cents vs. 94 cents a year earlier. Included in the new guidance was an impairment charge of 9 cents per share related to its Italian joint venture, Duferdofin Nucor.

But Nucor shares and key peers largely rallied Wednesday. Nucor's stock rose 9 cents to 36.20 Wednesday afternoon. U.S. Steel Corp. (X) climbed 0.5%. AK Steel Holding (AKS) advanced 1.2%. Arcelor Mittal (MT), though, dipped 0.9%.

Overall, steel makers did not react strongly to the news as the flood of cheap imports was expected and priced in. Steel stocks have tumbled in recent months as slowing global economic growth and Europe's rising woes push down commodity prices.
The Steel-Producers group is rated No. 185 out of IBD's 197 industries.
Steel and rebar imports began increasing at the end of 2011 and has continued through the start of 2012, according to Nucor.

"Although the U.S. market continues to show stable to slightly improving demand for steel, this surge in imports has undercut seasonal pricing momentum that is normally experienced early in the calendar year," the company said in a statement.

Nucor said it was able to post a profit in May for its three main construction products groups, rebar fabrication, joist and decking and pre-engineered metal buildings.Nucor (NUE) issued a warning on its second-quarter profit on Wednesday as a deluge of cheap steel imports from Turkey and Russia have put pressure on prices.The No. 2 U.S. steel company sees Q2 earnings of 35-40 cents per share, well below analyst expectations of 56 cents vs. 94 cents a year earlier. U.S. Steel topped Wall Street's estimates, but AK Steel fell short on earnings. And yet, U.S. Steel shares fell 18 cents in early afternoon trading Tuesday to 28.04 while AK Steel jumped 4.1% to 7.64. Nucor[tickerâ¦
Robust gains in Steel Dynamics (STLD) and Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF) pushed the global steel makers ETF ahead of the stock market Tuesday.

After severely underperforming the market for the past four years, many of the ETF's underlying holdings have formed bullish, cup-with-handle patterns. This suggests they may be forming a bottom and have started to recover from historically low demand.
In afternoon trade, Market Vectors Steel ETF (SLX) was up 2% vs. 0.33% for the SPDR S&P 500 (SPY).

SLX holds 27 steel producers from eight countries, mainly the U.S. The chart for SLX appears to have formed a bullish, three-month long, cup-with-handle base with a 49.66 buy point. It trades above both its 50-day moving average and 200-day moving average, which confirms that it's in a strong uptrend.

SLX severely lagged the market the past two years, melting 33% in 2011 and gaining only 4.72% in 2012, while SPY rose 2% and 16% in those periods. But SLX has taken the lead in the short run, climbing 11% in the past three months, while SPY added 7%.

It holds a rather weak IBD Relative Strength Rating of 38, which means its price performance has lagged 62% of the market over the past 12 months. Its IBD Accumulation-Distribution Rating of C on an A-to-E scale indicates institutional buying evens out with the selling.
Steel Dynamics, which makes up 4% of the ETF, shot up nearly 3% Tuesday to 15.40. It has broken out of a bullish, cup-with-handle pattern with a 14.64 buy point.

The company reported fourth-quarter profit that topped guidance and issued a positive outlook Monday evening. Earnings flew 93% year over year, snapping three quarters of zero growth. Sales dipped 8%. Jefferies analysts rated the stock hold.

"Steel Dynamics' outlook was positive but a bit vague/high level, citing 'potential' for building momentum in auto and manufacturing markets and noting areas indicating signs of improvement in nonresidential construction, from historically low levels currently," analyst Luke Folta and his colleague wrote in a client note. "To date in January, spot market demand/price trends for both steel and scrap have been far weaker than expected, lacking the positive seasonal momentum typically observed this time of the year."

United States Steel (X), weighted at 4% in SLX, reported a less-than-expected fourth-quarter loss Monday, mainly owing to lower costs. Jefferies also rated it hold, noting that it issued a "disappointing" first-quarter outlook.

"Results in North American Flat-Rolled (steel) are expected to be near break-even, despite higher shipments and spot pricing along with lower roll mill costs, due to lower average selling price on lagging index-based contract and higher maintenance costs," Folta wrote.
United States Steel shares dipped nearly 2% but they appear to have found support at their 50-day moving average. It also formed a bullish cup-with-handle chart pattern with a 26.39 buy point.

Nucor (NUE), weighted 5% in SLX, beat fourth-quarter estimates but guided lower for the first quarter. It shed 0.09% to 47.15. It's trading 12% above a 42.10 buy point in a long cup-with-handle pattern.

"Nucor noted some small improvement in construction markets, though noted that activity remains at historically anemic levels," Folta wrote in a client note. "Markets where demand is said to be the strongest continue to be manufactured goods including automotive, energy and heavy equipment."
Q4 earnings climbed 22% year over year, breaking a three-quarter string of stagnation. Sales dipped 8% year over year.
Cliffs Natural Resources jumped 2% to 36.01. Standard & Poor's rates it a hold.

"We believe the shares are fairly valued, currently trading at about 9.3 times our 2013 earnings per share estimate. And, with a dividend yield of over 8%, we believe that the market is already pricing in a possible reduction in the dividend," S&P wrote.

"Longer term, Cliff's strong market position in North America's iron ore market provides it with a solid platform for expansion in Asia and the ability to enter new markets such as ferrochrome. We believe Cliff's sales and earnings will rise on a combination of expansions at existing mines, continued consolidation of the global iron ore mining industry, and a secular increase in steel consumption in most of Asia."
The chart for Cliff is in a downtrend and hasn't formed a noteworthy pattern.

ArcelorMittal (MT), the world's largest steelmaker, expects to write down the value of its European business by $4.3 billion this quarter, as Europe struggles to free itself from its debt quagmire.
The write-down came after the Netherlands-based company completed a government-mandated yearly financial test.
ArcelorMittal cited the weak global economy and market environment in Europe, where demand for steel has fallen by an estimated 8% this year, bringing cumulative total drop to 29% since 2007.
Shares of the struggling steelmaker fell 3.3% to 16.95 in Friday afternoon trading.
Earning per share and sales shrank throughout 2012 and it missed analyst consensus for EPS growth the last three quarters in a row.
A Wednesday report from the World Steel Association said global steel output in November was down 2.7% from the prior month but up 5.1% compared to the same month a year ago.
European production fell 4.2% for the month, from a year earlier. But North American production rose a bit.
Among U.S. steelmakers, United States Steel (X)slid 3% Friday afternoon, while AK Steel (AKS) dropped 4.5% and Nucor (NUE) was down 1.1%.
RBC Capital Markets said U.S. steel production continued to grow in early December.

"In addition, for the first three weeks of December, AISI (American Iron and Steel institute) figures indicate a 2.8% month-over-month rise in U.S. daily output rates and an increase in the U.S. steel capacity utilization rate to 73.9% in mid-December."

Among top-rated companies in the Steel-Producers group, ranked a relatively strong 39 on IBD's list of 197 industries, TMS International (TMS), based in Glassport, Pa., dipped 1%. TMS' stock sports an 89 Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 89% of all stocks based on key metrics, such as sales and profit growth.

Mexico's Grupo Simec (SIM), with an 88 Composite Rating, was down 1.5%.ArcelorMittal (MT), the world's largest steelmaker, expects to write down the value of its European business by $4.3 billion this quarter, as Europe struggles to free itself from its debt quagmire.The write-down came after the Netherlands-based company completed a government-mandated yearly financial test.ArcelorMittal cited the weak global economy and market environment in Europe, where demand for steel has fallen by an estimated 8% this year, bringing cumulative total drop to 29% since 2007.Shares of the struggling steelmaker fell 3.3% to 16.95 in Friday afternoon trading.Earning per share and sales shrank throughout 2012 and it missed analyst consensus for EPS growth the last three quarters in a row.A Wednesday report from the World Steel Association said global steel output in November was down 2.7% from the prior month but up 5.1% compared to the same month a year ago.European production fell 4.2% for the month, from a year earlier. But North American production rose a bit.Among U.S. steelmakers, United States Steel (X)slid 3% Friday afternoon, while AK Steel (AKS) dropped 4.5% and Nucor (NUE) was down 1.1%.RBC Capital Markets said U.S. steel production continued to grow in early December."In addition, for the first three weeks of December, AISI (American Iron and Steel institute) figures indicate a 2.8% month-over-month rise in U.S. daily output rates and an increase in the U.S. steel capacity utilization rate to 73.9% in mid-December."Among top-rated companies in the Steel-Producers group, ranked a relatively strong 39 on IBD's list of 197 industries, TMS International (TMS), based in Glassport, Pa., dipped 1%. TMS' stock sports an 89 Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 89% of all stocks based on key metrics, such as sales and profit growth.Mexico's Grupo Simec (SIM), with an 88 Composite Rating, was down 1.5%.

Steel makers U.S. Steel (X) and smaller AK Steel (AKS) are slated to report results Tuesday, opening a window on prospects for the sector and the global economy this year. Nucor (NUE) was the first steel company to report, announcing first-quarter results Thursday. Shares dropped 6% in two days after the company said profit slipped 16% to 42 cents aâ¦

Steelmaker shares tumbled Tuesday as construction and mining equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT) cut its 2015 profit outlook owing to global economic weakness. Analysts have a dismal outlook for the industry for the remainder of the year despite China's stealth building plans and global central banks printing money. Market Vectors Steel ETF (SLX), a basket of 27 global steel producers, droppedâ¦
Stock prices for Nucor (NUE) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) jumped after UBS raised its price target on the companies and said demand is strong. Some rival steel makers climbed even higher on the news.
UBS cited rising demand on general economic recovery, paired with shrunken inventories, which is leading to higher steel prices.
The bank raised Nucor and Steel Dynamics to a top rating, putting a price target of 47.50 on Nucor, up from 46 earlier.
It set Steel Dynamics' price target at 18, vs. 16 before.
Shares of Nucor, which makes hot-rolled steel and steel joists for various industries, advanced nearly 1.74% to 45 in late regular session trading.
The company was already participating in a broad advance. Its earnings per share rose 400%, 224% and 714% in the past three quarters, on double-digit hikes in revenue.

Steel Dynamics' stock price jumped nearly 3.29% to 15.53 in late session trading. The maker of flat-rolled, structural, bar and rail steels' EPS has spiked 95%, 122% and 100% the past three quarters, also on double-digit increases in sales.

Elsewhere in the sector, United States Steel (X), now up 16% for the month, soared 7% to 31.83. UBS said it expects U.S. Steel's EPS to grow faster in 2012, after lagging peers in 2011, with improved demand and higher prices, as it works to contain costs.
AK Steel (AKS) rose 4.8% to 8.59. Netherlands-based Arcelor-Mittal (MT) lifted 3.4% to 21.46, and Brazil's Companhia Siderurgica (SID) was up 0.8% to 10.82.
UBS, Citi and other analysts note that some steel makers have announced aggressive steel-price increases in recent weeks. If those stick, look for further gains in the sector.

"We may see buyers blinking and prices moving up from here," said UBS analyst Shneur Gershuni, in a client note. "Imports, quite attractive six weeks ago, should decrease and buyers may be forced to restock into rising prices."

Steel makers also hope to capitalize on record-low natural gas prices. Using the lower-cost fuel to fire furnaces could boost steel production and profits.Stock prices for Nucor (NUE) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) jumped after UBS raised its price target on the companies and said demand is strong. As horizontal hydraulic fracturing â fracking â pumps up production of oil and natural gas, prices have plunged. And that is creating new winners not only in segments of the energy sector, but also in industries ranging from transportation to steel making, chemicals, retailing and agriculture. "Fracking is opening supplies of energy. It's also cutting the cost of extracting energyâ¦

AK Steel (AKS) shares gapped down sharply in triple average volume after the No. 4 U.S. steel maker cut its fourth-quarter profit outlook and said it will issue 25 million new shares of stock, diluting the value of shares currently held.
The downward revision came amid falling steel prices on global economic weakness including China, the world's largest customer.
The company forecast a Q4 loss of 67-72 cents per share, compared with a 55-cent loss in Q3.
Consensus of 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters was for a 17-cent-a-share loss, vs. a 51-cent-a-share loss in the same quarter last year.
United States Steel (X), the nation's largest steel maker, on Oct. 30 also gave weak Q4 guidance, saying it expects an economic slowdown to hit this quarter.
AK Steel shares were down 14% in Tuesday afternoon trading, at 4.70 a share. U.S. Steel, the largest U.S. steel maker, was down 1.5% intraday.
Steel prices have fallen in recent months mainly because of slower growth in China, the world's largest consumer of steel, and continued economic weakness in Europe.

AK Steel expects to ship more steel this quarter than in Q3, but said the average selling price for all of its steel products will fall about 5% in Q4 from the average selling price so far in 2012 of $1,073 per ton.
The steel maker also announced a private offering of $350 million in senior notes due in 2018. It intends to use proceeds to repay borrowings and for general purposes.

Meanwhile, U.S. Steel has beaten analysts' profit forecasts the last three quarters in a row, but its share price has bounced in a narrow range since May amid weakness in both the U.S. and European markets.
Its stock has a lackluster IBD Composite Rating of 23 out of a best-possible 99.

ArcelorMittal (MT), the world's largest steel producer, slid 0.5% Tuesday afternoon. The company said on Oct. 31 that it plans to cut its dividend to 20 cents a share in 2013, and finance chief Aditya Mittal said the industry is going through "very challenging operating conditions," exacerbated by Europe's long-drawn-out debt crisis.

Smaller but highly rated Mexican steel producer Grupo Simec (SIM) dropped 1%. And U.S. Steel's American rival Nucor (NUE), which also earlier warned it expects lower earnings this quarter, edged down a few cents.AK Steel (AKS) shares gapped down sharply in triple average volume after the No. 4 U.S. steel maker cut its fourth-quarter profit outlook and said it will issue 25 million new shares of stock, diluting the value of shares currently held.The downward revision came amid falling steel prices on global economic weakness including China, the world's largest customer.The company forecast a Q4 loss of 67-72 cents per share, compared with a 55-cent loss in Q3.Consensus of 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters was for a 17-cent-a-share loss, vs. a 51-cent-a-share loss in the same quarter last year.United States Steel (X), the nation's largest steel maker, on Oct. 30 also gave weak Q4 guidance, saying it expects an economic slowdown to hit this quarter.AK Steel shares were down 14% in Tuesday afternoon trading, at 4.70 a share. And U.S. Steel's American rival Nucor (NUE), which also earlier warned it expects lower earnings this quarter, edged down a few cents.

Oil and natural gas prices took hits on Monday, but the stock market still wasn't able to make headway. After jumping at the opening bell, the Nasdaq and NYSE indexes began to slouch about 40 minutes into the session. Before the day was over, the major indexes undercut their recent lows. A late bounce-back trimmed some losses. Volume was aboveâ¦
5:15 p.m. Update:Â Markets ended softly higher Tuesday, a welcome change Â at first glance Â from Monday's tumble on rising volume.

The advance broadened throughout the day, spreading from fewer than 50% of industry groups posting advances in morning trading to nearly 95% of the 197 groups tracked by IBD posting gains by the close.
A kick up in oil prices helped spread the joy, pulling stocks like Layne Christensen (LAYN), T-3 Energy Services (TTES) and Cal Dive International (DVR) to better-than 10% gains.

But leading stocks showed little verve, making the day an iffy sign coming on the heels of a distribution day. The market needs up days on higher volume, down days on soft volume, if the rally is to survive.

In after hours action, Darden Restaurants (DRI) jumped 6%, adding to a 4% gain during the regular session. The operator of the Red Lobster and Olive Garden chains is scheduled to release it Q4 earnings after the close, but had not reported as this update went to press.
MGM Mirage (MGM) spiked 7% in extended trading, reversing a 6%, regular session loss.
On the downside, Guess (GES) dove 2%, erasing its 3% gain in regular session trading. After hours fourth quarter reports from MGM and Guess were also pending.

Wednesday sports a busy economic calendar. The consumer price index is due from the Labor Department prior to the market open. The Energy Information Administration reports weekly crude oil inventories after 10:30 a.m. EDT, and the Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to deliver a decision on interest rates near 2:15 p.m. EDT.
Wednesday's earnings calendar includes a report from General Mills (GIS) before the market opens, and Excel Maritime (EXM), IHS (IHS) and Oracle (ORCL) after the closing bell.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close At Session Highs
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed at session highs as it rebounded from Monday's sell-off.
The Nasdaq's 4.1% surge led the market. The S&P 500 jumped 3.2%, the NYSE composite 2.9%, the Dow 2.5%.
Preliminary readings showed lower volume. If confirmed, that would put a damper on an otherwise strong advance.
Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-2 on the Nasdaq and 11-to-3 on the NYSE.
Technology stocks led on bullish analyst comments about Cisco Systems (CSCO). Internet stocks were among the day's other winners.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Hold Near Highs Amid Broad Gains

5:15 p.m. Update:Â Major stock indexes erased early gains and closed lower again Tuesday.
Upbeat housing and tame wholesale inflation data offset lackluster production data at the open. But stocks turned red shortly before the lunch hour and then kept falling.

The NYSE composite and S&P 500 dropped 1.3% each. Both are nearing their respective 200-day moving averages. The Dow slipped further below its 200-day line, losing 1.2%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell 1.1%.
Turnover rose slightly on both exchanges.
Several leaders again took hits.
Changyou.com (CYOU) erased early gains and lost 8% in heavy trading. The Chinese online gamer continued its slide after reversing from a record high Thursday.

Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT) slid 6% in active trading and closed just shy of its 50-day moving average. The stock has now lost ground for five of the past six sessions, with all five down days in heavy volume.
Fuqi International (FUQI) dropped 4% in brisk trade. The Chinese jeweler fell for the fourth straight session and sits 23% off Wednesday's 52-week high.
On the bright side, STEC (STEC) gapped up and flew 27% to a new high in monster trade. The memory products guided Q2 earnings and sales well ahead of views.

HMS Holdings (HMSY) gapped up and gained 3% to an all-time high in over twice its average trade. The stock cleared a 38.38 buy point from a high handle. HMS' buy point was incorrectly stated at 38.82 in prior updates.
Data on May consumer prices will be out Wednesday, as well as earnings from FedEx (FDX) and IHS (IHS).
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close At Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks tumbled following a mixed bag of economic data Tuesday, finishing at session lows.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 1.3% each. The Dow and Nasdaq dropped 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively.
Volume rose on both exchanges. Losers beat advancers by more than 2-to-1 on both exchanges.
Health care and school issues were Tuesday's best performers. Retail, dairy and oil producers were among the biggest decliners.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retain Losses In Late-Day Action
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes were on track for a second straight day of losses with less than an hour left in Tuesday's session.
The Nasdaq fell 0.8%, the Dow 0.9% and the S&P 500 1%. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite shed 1.2%.
Volume continued to track lower across the board Â a bit of a relief.
On a tough day for several metals stocks, BHP Billiton (BHP) fell 4% on nearly twice its normal trade. The Australian mining company remains above its 50-day moving average.
Factset Research Systems (FDS) lost 2% in brisk turnover. The financial data provider has now fallen to 26% off its 52-week high.
On the upside, Citi Trends (CTRN) rose 2% in above-average volume. The clothing chain's stock has rebounded above its 50-day line and is on track for its fourth straight day of gains.
2:15 p.m. Update: Market Holds Lower In Light Trade

5:15 p.m. Update:Â Major stock indexes suffered their biggest hit thus far this month as economic fears weighed from the opening bell.
The NYSE composite shed 3%, dragged down by commodity-related issues. The S&P 500 dropped 2.4% and Nasdaq 2.3%. Meanwhile, the Dow fell 2.1% and breached its 200-day moving average.
Volume climbed across the board, especially on the NYSE.
Metal and steel stocks crumbled.
RTI International Metals (RTI) and Allegheny Technologies (ATI) shed 10% and 6%, respectively.
Olympic Steel (ZEUS) and ArcelorMittal (MT) dropped 7% each.
A few leaders faltered.
Fuqi International (FUQI) tumbled 8% in brisk trade. But the Chinese jeweler held above Friday's low.

Neutral Tandem (TNDM) lost 5% in heavy trading. Since hitting an all-time high June 2, the telecom service provider lost ground for six of the past nine sessions. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution has fallen to D from B+ earlier this month.
Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) gapped down and lost 5% in nearly twice its average trade. Despite the drop, the Chinese Internet gaming firm still sits 61% past a 33.70 buy point.
On the upside, 99 Cents Only Stores (NDN) reversed early losses and rose 2% to a near two-year high. That extended the discount retailer's 32% increase last week.
Baidu (BIDU) reversed losses and edged up just over 1%.
On deck to report earnings Tuesday are Adobe Systems (ADBE), Best Buy (BBY), FactSet Research (FDS) and Smithfield Foods (SFD).
Data on housing starts, building permits, producer prices, capacity utilization and industrial production will also be out Tuesday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retreat In Heavy Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks sold off across the board Monday, but a round of late buying trimmed some losses.
The NYSE composite tumbled 3%, S&P 500 2.4%, Nasdaq 2.3% and Dow 2.1%.
Decliners swamped advancers by over 5-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Volume surged on the NYSE and rose a bit on the Nasdaq.
Just about all 197 industry groups tracked by IBD lost ground. Steel and commodity-related groups were among the hardest hit.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retain Losses In Higher Volume
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes were on pace for losses in higher volume with less than an hour to go in Monday's session.
The NYSE composite tumbled 3.3%, the Nasdaq 2.8%, the S&P 500 2.7% and the Dow 2.5%.
Volume continued to track higher across the board.
A number of top-rated stocks continued to pare recent gains.
Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) dropped 5% in above-average volume.
China-based online gaming company Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) skidded 5% in nearly twice its normal trade, putting the stock on pace for its fourth straight loss.
Much of the market's losses were triggered by bigger-name stocks, though. Among Dow components Boeing (BA) lost 4%, while Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), Chevron (CVX) and 3M (MMM) all gave up 3%.
2:15 p.m. Update: Market's Rough Day Wears On

5:15 p.m. Update:Â Stocks skidded Monday after the Obama administration rejected turnaround plans from General Motors and Chrysler. Worries that banks would need more capital also dinged the market.
The NYSE composite lost 3.9%, the S&P 500 3.5%, the Dow 3.3% and the Nasdaq 2.8%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, marking a distribution day for the Dow, S&P 500 and NYSE. Nasdaq volume slipped from Friday's level.

Bankruptcy fears for automakers resurfaced after President Obama refused to throw them another lifeline, saying that more concessions need to be made. Shares of General Motors (GM) gapped down and dived 25% in over quadruple average trade.
Ford (F), which had said it doesn't need government aid, fell 3%.
Worries over financials were also rekindled after Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said in a weekend interview that banks will likely need "large amounts of assistance."
Bank of America (BAC) tumbled 18%, Wells Fargo (WFC) 14% and Citigroup (C) 12%.

Despite the heavy losses in the major indexes, most leaders escaped heavy selling. About 70 IBD 100 issues finished lower, but most in below-average trade. The median price change in the IBD 100 was -1.1%.
Terra Nitrogen (TNH) dropped 6% in nearly twice its average trade. Last week, the fertilizer maker passed the left side of a cup base, but in weak volume.
Quality Systems (QSII) gapped down and lost 6% after UBS lowered shares to sell from neutral.
On the upside, Netflix (NFLX) erased early losses and rallied 6% in fast trade. The movie rental firm said it would raise Blu-ray Disc rental prices by 20%.
On Tuesday, Apollo Group (APOL) reports quarterly results after the close. Before the open, the S&P/Case-Shiller home price index will be released.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Sharply Lower; Volume Appears Lower
BY VINCENT MAO
A late-session rebound trimmed some losses, but indexes still closed with sharp declines Monday.
The NYSE composite fell 3.9%, the Dow 3.5% and the S&P 500 3.3%. All three breached their 50-day moving averages. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped a milder 2.8% and held above its 50-day line.
Volume fell on both exchanges compared with Friday's levels, according to early readings. Declining stocks trashed advancers by 7-to-1 on the NYSE and by more than 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Extend Losses In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Most major indexes stumbled to new session lows late Monday. Only the Nasdaq escaped that fate.
The NYSE composite shed 4.6%, the S&P 500 4.2%, the Dow 4.1% and the Nasdaq 3.6%.
Volume was again tracking lower across the board. Decliners trounced advancers by 9-to-1 on the NYSE and by more than 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Nearly all 197 industry groups tracked by IBD were holding losses. Besides the steel, machinery and auto parts supplier groups, home builders were also under pressure.
Hovnanian Enterprises (HOV) slumped 18%, Lennar (LEN) 16%, Centex (CTX) 15%. The S&P/Case-Shiller index of home prices for January comes out Tuesday.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Near Lows As Recovery Efforts Wane
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks hovered near session lows as rebound efforts softened in the latter half of Monday's session.
The NYSE composite was down 4.2%, the S&P 500 3.7%, the Dow 3.6%, the Nasdaq 3.3%.
Turnover was again tracking lower on both exchanges.
Decliners swamped advancers by more than 8-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Financials were among the worse for wear.
Bank of America (BAC) fell 15%, Wells Fargo (WFC) 9%, Citigroup (C) 8%.
Despite the sell-off, a couple of leaders firmed up.
Aaron Rents (RNT) erased morning losses and rallied 6% in fast trade. The furniture and electronics rental firm reports earnings April 28. Analysts see profit climbing 33% to 52 cents per share.
NetEase.com (NTES) turned a 5% deficit into a 2% gain. Last week, the Chinese online gaming firm logged its fifth straight weekly gain in above-average volume.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Trim Losses In Early Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
After sinking from the open, the major indexes pared some losses in early afternoon trading Monday.

The NYSE composite was down 3.8%, narrowing a 4.2% deficit. The Dow and S&P 500 were off 3.4% each, while the Nasdaq fell 2.9%. With the exception of the Nasdaq, all indexes were back below their respective 50-day moving averages.
Volume was tracking slightly lower across the board.

General Motors (GM) had been down 34%, but trimmed its loss to 20%. The uncertain fate of the auto industry rippled through parts suppliers and steel makers. TRW Automotive Holdings (TRW) and American Axle & Manufacturing (AXL) tumbled 23% and 19%, respectively. Nucor (NUE) and U.S. Steel (X) fell 12% each.

Agrium (AGU) gapped down and dropped 8% in heavy trading. But the stock appeared to be finding support at its 50-day moving average. Earlier Monday morning, CF Industries (CF) had rejected Agrium's sweetened buyout offer. CF shares fell 4%.
American Italian Pasta (AIPC) reversed early gains and shed 6%. The pasta maker turned tail after hitting a near-five-year high. The stock has been bouncing off its 10-week line in weak volume.
Upside movers were few.

InterDigital (IDCC) rallied 8% after announcing restructuring plans. The wireless firm will cut 100 jobs for a savings of about $33 million a year, it said. It also plans to end production of its SlimChip modems and license its technology instead.
12:15 Update: Major Indexes Hold On To Losses, But Volume Levels Ease
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks continued to struggle Monday, but slowing volume took a bit of the sting out of early losses.
The Nasdaq dived 3.8%, the S&P 500 and Dow industrials 3.7% each. The NYSE composite skidded 4.2%.
The last time the benchmark S&P index posted a loss that big was March 5, the day before the market bottomed out and started its rapid rebound.
Volume slowed compared with heated earlier levels. Nasdaq volume was up less than 1% vs. the same time span Friday, while NYSE trade was down less than 1%.

NVE Corp. (NVEC) tumbled 9% in nearly four times its typical turnover. The maker of spintronic magnetic sensors, which owns accelerating quarterly sales and earnings growth, sliced through its 50- and 200-day moving averages.

Quality Systems (QSII), one of the few leading stocks to break out during the current rally, gapped down 6% in brisk volume. The provider of electronic records management software for the health care industry fell after UBS downgraded the stock to sell from a neutral rating.

On the upside, American Public Education (APEI) gained 6% in twice its normal trade. The provider of online postsecondary education has consolidated for the past 6 1/2 months. The stock went public in November 2007.
11:15 Update: Stocks' Losses Grow In Higher Volume

5:15 p.m. Update:Â Volume picked up in afternoon trading, apparently marking a follow-through rally confirmation for the NYSE indexes.
Current information showed volume ended higher on both major exchanges, a necessary ingredient for a follow-through.
Medical sectors issues led the gains through most of the day, overpowering some weak economic news and a credit downgrade on General Electric (GE).
Financials kicked in and took control later in the day, after Bank of America (BAC) Chief Executive Kenneth Lewis said his bank wouldn't need additional bailout funding to get through the recession.
Oil prices pitched in to drive energy stocks higher, with the April crude contract spiking 11% to above $47 a barrel. April natural gas jumped more than 5%.

In after-hours trading, Aeropostale (ARO) dropped 5%. The speciality teen retailer reported Q4 earnings gained 31%, above analyst expectations. The company guided first-quarter earnings below expectations. Shares are climbing out of a deep consolidation.

Smith & Wesson  (SWHC) rose 13%, adding to a 15% spike in the regular session. The firearms maker reported fiscal Q3 earnings of five cents, above views. Shares are working their way up the right side of a cup-shaped base.

Friday's economic calendar includes the release of February export and import prices and January trade balance data from the Labor and Commerce departments before the market opens. The University of Michigan will deliver its preliminary consumer sentiment index numbers for March at 10 a.m. EDT.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Surge, But Volume Is Questionable
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market closed sharply higher Thursday, though volume wasn't impressive.
The Nasdaq, NYSE composite and S&P 500 soared 4%, while the Dow was up 3.4% at the closing bell.
Volume rose on the Nasdaq but fell on the NYSE, according to early readings. Higher volume on the NYSE would have marked a follow-through on those indexes' new rally attempt.

Financials led after Bank of America  (BAC) CEO Kenneth Lewis said the bank was profitable in January and February, echoing remarks from Citigroup (C) and JPMorgan (JPM) CEOs earlier this week. Lewis also said BofA should be able to get through the recession without new help from taxpayers.
Health care stocks also were strong after Gilead Sciences (GILD) agreed to acquire CV Therapeutics  (CVTX).
3:15 p.m. Update: Rally Holds As Nasdaq Volume Goes Green

5:15 p.m. Update:Â Stocks took a breather after a two-day run-up, ending lower in soft volume as oil and commodities pulled back, and amid more bad news on the economy.
The Dow dove 2.7% after glancing off resistance at its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 gave up 2.3%. The NYSE lost 2.1% and the Nasdaq 1.6%.
On the Dow, 27 of 30 components ended lower. On the S&P 500, AutoZone (AZO), Google (GOOG) and Jacobs Engineering (JEC) posted the best gains. Small caps fell harder, with the S&P 600 diving 3.1%.
Preliminary data showed NYSE volume ran well below Tuesday's above-average action. Nasdaq trading ran almost even with the prior session's below-average levels.
For Wednesday, not much is due out in terms of economic reports. Wholesale inventories are scheduled to be reported.

Weekly crude inventory and refinery data is set for release from the Energy Information Administration and the American Petroleum Institute at 10 a.m. EST, although changes in oil inventories and refinery activity have imposed little to no effect on crude prices in recent weeks.
More important is the view toward OPEC's next meeting on Dec. 17, in which analysts generally expect a decision for a notable decrease in the group's production quota.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Near Session Lows
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The major indexes closed near session lows Tuesday, giving up a chunk of Monday's gains.
The Dow fronted the losses, sliding 2.7%. The S&P 500 tumbled 2.3%, the NYSE composite 2.1%, the Nasdaq 1.6%, according to preliminary figures.
Volume was lower across the board, though much more so on the NYSE.
Freight and other transportation groups were weak after FedEx (FDX) cut its fiscal 2009 outlook. Finance and some consumer-related groups also lagged.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Slide In Late Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Selling pressure picked up late Tuesday, pushing the major indexes to new session lows.

The Dow tumbled 2.6% and erased the bulk of Monday's rise. It turned tail after meeting resistance at its 50-day moving average. Twenty-seven of the 30 components traded lower. JPMorgan (JPM) and General Electric (GE) were its biggest percentage decliners, down 7% each. Walt Disney (DIS) dropped 5%. The leisure and entertainment giant said that theme park bookings improved, but advertising continued to be weak.

Meanwhile, the NYSE and S&P 500 fell 2.3% and 2%, respectively. The Nasdaq lost 1.5%. The Philadelphia semiconductor index gained 3.6%, but that's down from an intraday high of 8.4%. The Nasdaq 100 fell 0.9%, but Google (GOOG) and Apple (AAPL) hung on to small gains.
Turnover remained mixed with NYSE trading lower and Nasdaq higher.

On the upside, shipping issues bucked weakness among transportation stocks. Excel Maritime Carriers (EXM), DryShips  (DRYS) and Genco Shipping & Trading (GNK) vaulted 31%, 25% and 13% respectively. All three have been recovering from huge sell-offs in recent weeks.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Weaken As Volume Picks Up
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks turned decidedly lower in afternoon trading, as volume picked up as the selling progressed.
The Dow dipped 1.6%, the S&P 500 1% and the NYSE composite 0.7%. The Nasdaq fared best, off just 0.2%. Volume was higher on the Nasdaq, lower on the NYSE.
Panera Bread (PNRA), a national bakery and cafe chain, edged up, but gave up most of a 4% gain from earlier in the day. The stock is in a cup-shaped base with steep left and right sides.
Steel maker Nucor (NUE) gained 5%. The company said it expects profit to be just above break-even in Q4. Analysts guide for $1.46 a share.
Pre-Paid Legal Services (PPD), a thin micro-cap, rose 2%. Smith Thomas, a director at the provider of legal services, sold more than 44,000 shares on the open market, valued at over $1.6 million.

On the downside, Granite Construction (GVA) dropped 7%. The civil construction firm has been rising out of what could be a pullback to the 10-week moving average or a cup-with-handle with heavy overhead supply.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Improve In Midday Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained mixed at midday Tuesday, but the market's tone improved.
The NYSE composite and S&P 500 joined the Nasdaq in positive territory, though the Dow remained lower.
The Nasdaq was up 1%, the NYSE composite 0.3%, the S&P 500 a fraction. The Dow fell 0.9%.
Turnover was mixed, with NYSE volume lower and Nasdaq trading running higher.

PriceSmart (PSMT) rallied 7% in heavy trading, extending its recent win streak. The company operates warehouse club stores in Central America and the Caribbean. PriceSmart is climbing back toward its 200-day moving average. It has been trading under the line for nearly seven months.
World Fuel Services (INT) added almost 4% to a fresh 52-week high. The marketer of marine, aviation and land fuel products was one of the top percentage gainers in the IBD 100.
On the downside, Baidu.com  (BIDU) erased early gains and shed 7% in brisk volume. The Chinese Internet search giant was up about 6% earlier.
Rival Perfect World (PWRD) gapped down and lost 3% in fast trade. The online gaming firm had been recovering from an all-time low, but it met resistance at its 50-day line recently.
12:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq Hangs Tough While Others Struggle
BY VINCENT MAO
Rebound efforts waned near the halfway point of Tuesday's session. The Nasdaq remained positive, but well off session highs.

The Nasdaq gained 0.3%, down from session highs of 2%. But the Philadelphia semiconductor index upped its gain to 6.6%. Besides chip issues, bellwethers Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOG) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) scored nice gains. Meanwhile, the Dow lost 1.3%, S&P 500 0.8% and NYSE composite 0.6%.
Volume remained sharply lower on the NYSE and slightly higher on the Nasdaq.

Netflix (NFLX) powered up 8% in heavy trading. But there was no news on the jump. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B from D since late last month. Despite a slowing economy, the movie-rental firm's sales growth accelerated the last couple of quarters.
Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) added nearly 3% and neared a 31.12 buy point from a double-bottom base. The Chinese online gaming firm has surged over 50% since touching a 52-week low Dec. 1.

On the downside, AECOM Technology (ACM) fell 3% in brisk volume as it pulled back from two days of big gains. That left the government contractor 9% past a 27.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.
American Public Education (APEI) lost 4% and breached its 200-day moving average.
11:15 a.m. Update: Nasdaq Leads Rebound Efforts
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks shrugged off most of their opening losses and turned mixed early Tuesday. Despite warnings from a number of chip-related issues, the Nasdaq led the pack and chips shot higher.
Equities once again battled back from bad news, continuing a recent pattern. But it was still early in the session.

The Nasdaq turned a 1.8% loss into a 1.4% gain. The Philadelphia semiconductor index leapt 6.5%. Texas Instruments (TXN), National Semiconductor (NSM), Altera (ALTR) and Broadcom (BRCM) rebounded from early losses.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and S&P 500 gained 0.5% and 0.3%, respectively. The Dow remained the sole loser, down 0.4%.
Volume was still tracking much lower on the NYSE, but turned slightly higher on the Nasdaq.

AutoZone (AZO) rallied 7% and regained its 50-day moving average after it delivered fiscal Q1 earnings above views. The auto parts retailer reported profit of $2.23 a share, up from $2.02 a year ago and a nickel above views. However, the rise in earnings was due to few shares outstanding.

Nordic American Tanker Shipping (NAT) rallied 4% in fast trade and closed in on its 200-day moving average. The shipper sailed higher for the sixth straight session. Earnings last quarter flew 854%, and analysts see another triple-digit gain this period.
Almost Family (AFAM) added 3% as it continued to build the right side of a new base. Mutual fund ownership of the home nursing care provider has more than tripled from two quarters ago.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Open Lower On Light Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks opened lower Tuesday following a round of layoffs and profit warnings. An early comeback was quickly shot down.
The Dow fell 1.5%, the NYSE composite 0.8% and the Nasdaq 0.3%. The S&P 500 declined 0.8%; earlier, it slipped under the 900 level.
Volume was tracking lower across the board.

In economic news, the pending home sales index for October declined 0.7% to 88.9 from an upwardly revised reading of 89.5 in September. The October dip was not as bad as expected. Lawrence Yun, chief economist of the National Association of Realtors, said that despite turmoil in the housing market, "the overall level of pending home sales has been remarkably stable over the past year, holding in a generally narrow range."
United Parcel Service (UPS) gapped down and shed 6% following FedEx's (FDX) late Monday warning. JPMorgan Chase downgraded UPS to neutral from overweight, citing slowing demand.

Trucking firm Con-way (CNW) gapped down and tumbled 9% after cutting its full-year outlook and announcing a round of layoffs. It now sees earnings from continuing operations in a range of $2.20 to $2.35 a share, down from prior guidance of $2.60 to $2.80. Analysts expected $2.78. Con-Way also said it would slash 1,450 jobs, or 8% of its work force.

Novellus Systems (NVLS) gapped down and dropped 5% on brisk volume. The chip equipment maker warned it expects to lose at least 15 cents a share in the fourth quarter vs. views for a loss of 4 cents a share. It also sees a 10% decline in sales and will cut 10% of its global workforce.
On the upside, Emergency Medical Services  (EMS) rallied 5% and regained its 50-day moving average.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Set To Take Early Breather
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks futures pointed to a weaker open Tuesday, as equities look to take a breather from two days of big gains.
Nasdaq futures dropped 15 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures lost 7 points and Dow futures gave up 86 points.

FedEx (FDX) tumbled 10% in the pre-market after cutting it 2009 profit outlook. Amid a sliding economy, the shipping giant now expects earnings in a range of $3.50 to $4.75 a share vs. views of $5.15.

Texas Instruments (TXN) also slashed its profit guidance. Late Monday, the world's largest maker of cell-phone chips lowered its Q4 outlook to 10 cents to 16 cents a share. That's down from a prior range of 30 cents to 36 cents and well below views of 31 cents. Shares slipped 2% in the pre-open.

Late Monday, National Semiconductor (NSM) reported a bigger-than-expected 58% decline in fiscal Q2 profit. Revenue fell 16%. The chipmaker sees Q3 sales falling 30% from the second quarter. Shares dropped 6% in the pre-market.
Group mates Altera (ALTR) and Broadcom (BRCM) also warned of lower sales ahead. They each slipped 1% in the pre-market.

Meanwhile, another round of companies unveiled layoffs. Sony (SNE) said it will slash 8,000 jobs in its electronics division and close plants in effort to save $1.1 billion in costs by March 2010. Another 8,000 temporary workers also are slated to lose their jobs.
After Monday's close, industrial and medical products maker Danaher (DHR) cut its Q4 profit outlook, slashed 1,700 jobs and announced plans to close 13 plants.
The Wyndham Hotel Group (WYN) will hack 4,000 jobs through the first quarter of 2009.
Elsewhere, automakers remain in focus. A $15 billion rescue package for General Motors (GM) and Chrysler might happen as soon as Wednesday.
On the economic front, data on October pending home sales will be out at 10 a.m. EST. Economists expect a 3% decline.

Also at that time, the the House Committee of Oversight and Government Reform will hold a hearing on the demise of mortgage giants Fannie Mae  (FNM) and Freddie Mac (FRE). Former chief executives from both firms will testify.5:15 p.m. Update:Â Stocks took a breather after a two-day run-up, ending lower in soft volume as oil and commodities pulled back, and amid more bad news on the economy.The Dow dove 2.7% after glancing off resistance at its 50-day moving average.
